THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH In the 1880s gold was discovered in what is now the most northern state of the USA Alaska. Many people came to the area hoping to get rich. New towns were built and grew quickly. One such town was called Iditarod which means 'far distant place'. The first race of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race was held on March 15, 1909. The Iditarod began in a small community called Willowdale in far northern Alaska. After this race the race was officially named the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race. The original prize money was $5000. It is now an amazing $20 million dollars. After the first race the Iditarod became a national treasure and was often referred to as the 'Great American Race' It is considered the last great race on earth. There is only one winner and every year when the race is run the winner is the one who has traveled the farthest. The only way to win the Iditarod is by driving a sled from Alaska to the North Pole, without stopping! As time passed the race has become so well known and well celebrated that people no longer travel from all over the world in order to attend the race. The people now travel by plane and train from all over the world in order to see this great race. Every year for two years the race is covered in white snow, but every year the winner is still the one who has traveled the farthest! This year the record for fastest dogs on the trail was set by a dog named Susie, a Norwegian sled dog, who reached the North Pole, in 1:29:18 on her first time trying the race. Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving the sport in which competitors reach extraordinary depths on only one breath of air. In 2003 Tanya Streeter made history when she became the first person to dive 120 metres into the ocean while holding her breath and come back up to the top without help. She became the first person to ever free-dive for 120 metres, but says she only does it "because it's something that I always wanted to do and that I am really good at." Since then, she has made free-diving a tradition. Nowadays, the sport is not popular on the island of Barbados and is not taken seriously, but Tanya says she will keep on doing it, because she loves it. "I think my passion is what I do. I do it for myself. My passion is what I love. I think I would be a bad sportsman and a bad person if I didn't do it." She also thinks her record-breaking attempt on the first anniversary of her world record attempt showed the public that she was not being a selfish diver. "To know that we did it together, everyone watching the live, everyone who was behind us in the stands. It shows that this is what we wanted to do. That is what we could do. Everyone that was supporting us, I was so happy." Photo: AFP "It's because I love it. There is something that we all have in common. We all love the water. We all love to be close to the water. It's just something that we can connect to." "I was really happy to see the world come to Barbados. It shows the whole world that Barbados is alive again." MONEY What is money? The pound the dollar or the franc are actually just like a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can exchange money for something else. A five pound note may buy a book a huge bag of sweets or a couple of cinema tickets. A dollar bill may buy an oil change or some food. The Australian dollar, the euro or the yen are also like this. The problem is you can't change it for something else. There is an exchange rate in the middle. What you are currently spending on money is what you are getting back for it. There may be a difference of one hundred to one but most of the time it is less than that. For example if you have an Australian dollar or a British pound in your pocket you are paying for a ticket to London but you don't have to pay much money. So it may be worth one pound to you but only a penny to the store clerk. How is that possible? Your dollar is worth exactly what you are currently spending it on. That's the exchange rate. If you change it for a dollar it is only changing it for the same amount of money. What is the exchange rate? How do they get it? It is calculated by a bank. The bank is paid a fee for allowing the exchange. The bank charges you less for its services if it has already exchanged for you what you wanted. This fee is called a swap rate. A pound costs around £0.50 (A US dollar) so the bank would be exchanging £0.50 for the pound. The bank gets a fixed fee for this service. So if you want to exchange your money for one US dollar it will cost £0.50. It also costs a small fee to the

The main and easiest one is the Skywalk. This walkway is located at the southern point of the Grand Canyon. At the top of the Skywalk is a wonderful view of the river.

Watering the Desert  It can rain at any time between November and March in Marrakesh Morocco. It doesn’t happen frequently and when it does the city’s water pipes can’t manage the sudden floods which turn the streets into rivers. But as many winters have remained dry in recent times when the rain does come it is welcomed by the local people. Because drought is a permanent threat. The area is particularly prone to fire. At present Morocco is facing a serious drought. To help people the government has distributed water canons and water-saving projects to villages. The government is trying to increase the supply of water to the country. But even if they succeed they are unlikely to be able to stop the recurrent drought.

Gareth Ellis Gareth Ellis 13 is the youngest son of Alan an engineer and Kath a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers but Gareth's dream was always to become a clown. Three years ago Alan Kath and Gareth joined the circus. 'People laugh when we tell them' says Kath. 'The circus doesn't just perform tricks and stunts, it is full of people with real feelings. The circus is a great way to make friends and learn to act as an adult. Circus training is the same as learning to swim - you have to be patient and try new things.' The circus also provides a new life for Alan who has been unemployed for a number of years. Gareth is now working hard and is helping his brothers with his clowning skills. His parents believe that 'the circus offers Gareth a fantastic chance to develop the skills he has always wanted and help his family and friends. 'We are all very proud of him. He is very brave and a great future clown.' Gareth is planning on starting the clown training in three weeks' time. He will train by performing tricks with a rubber ball. The ball will be changed and he will learn new tricks using different items. He will also do other things to improve his clowning and teaching abilities. 'I will learn as much about clowning as I can and I want to be the best clown in the whole world.' Gareth was in charge of the circus' costume shop and has been working in the costume department for the past two years. He is an enthusiastic buyer and has helped to source costumes. He is always on the look out for interesting costumes and always keeps an eye out for bargains. 'He always has something new in his dresser and he is always in demand, telling everyone he knows about great bargains.

Little Chefs For one group of children aged between ten and fifteen Saturdays are spent learning the art of serious cooking. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to do the course. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn how to make good food. They do not have to wait a few months like others do when they become unemployed.
The Chefs, trained by an experienced teacher, work at the Children’s home (formerly care homes) in the evenings, preparing lunch for all the children in a variety of recipes, most made with ingredients grown or bought locally. The local community help to buy the ingredients. This saves both money and time for the volunteers who spend the whole day in the kitchen.
For example, over the three weeks they are in the care home, the children prepare a vegetarian pot-luck lunch on Sunday for the staff who are present. It is an opportunity for the children to develop their skills and taste different flavours, all of which will be kept in the children’s mind as they go away to become chefs of the future.
The Chefs started as a pilot project and now their members have formed a self-relying network of chefs. They plan and cook at least twice a month for several hundred people. All food is sold and all income goes into helping the Children’s home. If enough people support it, they plan to build a restaurant which can provide high-quality food and accommodation for several hundred children who will grow up not knowing how to cook.
In the meantime, they have made a positive impression on young and old, who all hope to be a future chef too.
Sue, 16, lives in the care home with her sister, Lucy, 14

HONEY Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It consists of water and sugars. Bees may travel as far as seventy-five thousand kilometres and visit over two million flowers to produce just half a kilo of honey. The colour and flavour of honey depend on the type of flower visited. Honey bees live in the flower pollinating every day from sunrise to sunset.
10. The honey from a bee's nest contains a honeycombed comb of glands called a nectarine comb.: Honey comb is a honeycomb structure made of glands, called nectarine glands, called nectaries. These glands are located within a special layer on the outer covering of the comb called a honey veil. The nectaries are usually formed by a set of glands in the middle of the comb that produce a sticky liquid called honey. The glands are surrounded by the honey veil, which can be held closed by honey and/or wax. Nectaries and honey provide a unique honey scent. Honey can also contain pollen, wax, enzymes and other beneficial organisms.

To produce honey, bees extract nectar and pollen from flowers. Nectar and pollen are usually collected at sunrise or sunset on a warm day.
The pollen or nectar collected by bees is stored in the nectary glands. This is typically found in a nectar-producing bee. 
The nectar from flowers is not collected. Instead, it is processed and converted into honey.
11. Bees need to feed their young before they reproduce.: Bees feed their young with nectar and pollen. The young take a mixture of nectar and pollen. They collect nectar and pollen in special nectar sacs that are located in the bee's beak, called the operculum.

No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection New Writing 3 although I cannot understand why. Surely 500 pages of original writing of this quality for £6.99 is pretty amazing? Fiction - both parts of novels and complete short stories - makes up most of the book. There are some enjoyable pieces by famous writers such as Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Nonfiction - with some exceptions - is less worthwhile. A good deal of the book is taken up by interviews with writers. While this is useful for introducing the work to the public, in practice the interviews are rather weak and the writer rarely gets the opportunity to say what they mean by their work. Writing - whether fiction or nonfiction - should give an opportunity to express your point of view so it is disappointing to see such weak writing in the collected works. My favourite story is the first one which gives the readers a wonderful insight into the inner workings of some very famous and influential people in a very short and revealing story. I particularly enjoyed how this author describes the life of the world famous music manager and artist Michael Jackson. A number of this year's best-selling books are reviewed on a separate page. Other books which have been good include: How to Write a Book (by Hilary Mantel) and An Adventure for Henry Ford: A History (by Steven Pressfield). The latter offers an interesting insight into how the man at the centre of our history made his mark. A few non-fiction books - on the subject of football, war and other things - also feature. The section on history in the new collections is well laid out and gives a good opportunity for learning and exploring the way in which we understand the past.

Changing lives with a Stranger Mandie Currie a zoo-keeper spent the day in the offices of the magazine Marie Claire. 'Choosing what to wear for my day at Marie Claire was tricky because normally I wear a uniform at work. First I went to a still-life photo studio then to press previews all before lunch. Then it was time to work. On my desk were a couple of photos – one of me and the other one of the two women next to me. On my left side was a drawer where I placed my uniform, along with a lipstick tube, some pens, my ID card and my passport. My manager said I was to turn up at a certain time, so I'd put a message in my e-mail about getting there early. I also had to wear makeup, so I decided I should wear a dark pink lipstick and some blue mascara. I wasn't a big fan of my uniform because I always wore a green cardigan and skinny jeans, but I had to do this. I wanted to show that it wasn't just men in the office and I wanted to look different. On top of this, I was wearing a red scarf to cover my hair.' She shrugged and went on. 'I was working on the cover of Marie Claire's September/October 2006 issue. I was just about to go into the meeting of the editorial staff when my phone rang. It was a man called Mark who was the sales manager of the magazine and who I'd never met. I didn't know what to do. Onto a winner Two brothers are finding that their childhood game is very good for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse two bushy-bearded brothers in their forties are sitting in their modest home in Santa Fe in New Mexico USA and reliving their childhood. In front of them lies a wooden board covered in round plastic pieces.
It was their childhood game as well. It was "Rook & Key", a popular and highly popular game that has been passed from father to son for decades. It was one of those childhood games that every kid was excited to show his friends. Rook & Key was made by the popular children's toy company "Eddies". The main character was the Rook, a knight with a red hat with a golden staff, and the Key to open the castle was the Key with the white ball inside, which also appeared in the original Eddies Rook and Key game.
The brothers started this game back in their own home while their younger sister was visiting. Their mother had made a small board with the holes on both sides of the wooden pieces. Dave started with the Rook, then Norm started with the King, while the younger Dave started with the Knight. It was a very popular game.
The brothers started the game by placing the Rook on the board, with the white ball between two holes on both sides, at the center. They then started the game with the Knight. They moved their King one space to the left and the Rook one space to the right. The game was now completed.

Five minutes later Dr Kemp pulled down the window again and returned to his writing desk. He was not so happy now. He had heard the captain complaining about the storm. If the captain spoke his mind too strongly, then there was a danger that it would spread. And if the captain spoke too strongly, then his ship would not see the light of day for a long while. And if his ship did not see the light of day for a long while, then the men who worked on her would be even more unhappy than they were at present. He decided to listen to Captain MacIntyre, the ship's master. He was sure that he would know what to do, and so he began by asking him where the wind was blowing. Careless tourists scar ancient alpine rock art Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being gradually destroyed. Scientists and researchers fear that the 36000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so [line 6: beginning] rapidly that they will not survive for future generations.

"Careless tourists" are not the cause of this destruction. If anything, they are making it worse. They are taking away pieces of rock, damaging them, and then placing them in their cars to take them home. There's no system in place to remove the pictures once removed. There is no system in place to protect them from being damaged further on their journey.
[line 7: beginning] But the real culprits are the tourists who drive around picking up rock samples on their way up. Rock art experts are beginning to recognize certain sequences in the rock art. It's hard to be upset at tourists who visit a site and are happy to see the art that made that site famous. It's human nature to want to see art, no matter where it is located. But it also seems to me to be very difficult to preserve art when you have people who are just driving around trying to pick up rock samples, even though it is illegal to do so in certain places in the park. In this particular case, rock samples were found on the way up to the paintings. It seems to me that someone was driving around to find samples of rock that were on display, without realizing that they might pick up pieces of the art on the way.

No Title Finding a good flat in Dublin at a price you could afford was like finding gold in the gold rush. The best way was by personal contact: if you knew someone who knew someone who was leaving a place that often worked. And so you did, and when you showed up there was a bed in a hotel that said something about "Bed and Breakfast" in huge gold letters on the door, with the words "no night check" in blue chalk outline. But not for very long. 
  
 Then you had the hotel. But it seemed that your best and safest bet was in finding someone who had worked at the hotel and had a flat that they had left behind to find someone else. You looked carefully at the advertisements for guest houses, guest rooms, holiday apartments, student halls. And then one day there just appeared on the screen "House for sale. Large 4-bedroom flat. 2 bathrooms. Room available for rent now." And so you went to the advert and went round asking if anyone knew a guy who might have a flat for rent, and they knew a guy who knew the guy. And so on and so on, up to a room in a house, with an outdoor patio that a guy had rented for his two dogs, which was also available for rent. And then when you went home you had a room with a kitchen table and two chairs and maybe a couch or two. 
  
 I found the house by personal contact, which is the only way I know of, because the advertisements and the letters and the television news coverage simply didn't reach people who were looking for a flat. There was always one or two people in the hotel who had some spare room

Interview Tips First impressions are often lasting ones. Studies show that people form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress our eye contact our body movement and how fast or slowly we talk our volume and tone of voice as well as our our actual words. So how can we turn this negative first impression on our favor?
1. Smile. It's something many of us struggle with. But having a smile on your face will convey confidence, warmth, and warmth will get us a positive response.

Smile more. Smiling is contagious!

Make eye contact. Look them straight in the eyes and maintain eye contact. Eye contact helps us to project confidence in our personality.
2. Make your hair look nice. Your hair is important too! If you've let it become frizzy or damaged you're going to have a negative first impression. If it's straight and tied back, you'll have a welcoming look. Try and leave your hair alone and let it have the freedom to do what it wants to do.

Look for a great hairstyle. Some men and women get their look from hairstyle such as the one in the picture. Try to follow a similar hairstyle.
You could consider using a product such as styling paste or hairspray to keep your hair from frizzing so it doesn't look greasy in a new situation.
Try to keep your clothing neat. Avoid wearing baggy clothing that is a distraction. Try to stay in fitted clothes that show off your shape or your waist.
3. Practice your smile. Practice smiling on strangers. This will make you more confident and friendly as you come into a meeting.

Practice smiling by telling jokes and making fun of

What had happened? Where had she gone? There was much confusion on the stage and in the audience. Raoul had cried out. Count Philippe had jumped up in his box. People looked at them and wondered if this event was connected in any way with the paragraph in the morning's paper. The Countess Marie had been startled. She had been standing on stage for only a few seconds and at first had not realized what had happened. At that moment the orchestra had played the last notes of the programme and the last audience members had left the theatre. The Countess Marie looked towards the stage, where the actors and actresses were dressed in their costumes. Who is responsible for the theft?The Countess Marie was startled, but realized what had happened too late. She had, therefore, no time to think or to explain. In front of her, the theatre was empty, because the audience, who were all going back home, had already left. The Countess Marie, in her dressing-room, had no chance to talk to Raoul. When the actors and actresses had taken their places for the first rehearsal of the next day she had returned to her dressing-room. There, after changing into her costume, she had felt the knife in her pocket, but had not realized what had happened, until, at that moment, the orchestra had finished the programme, and the last audience had left the theatre. The Countess Marie had therefore not been able to inform Raoul that what he had seen on the stage the previous night was actually just a performance. Behind the dolphin's smile People love dolphins. We rush to look at them in seaside marinas films and TV programmes. Yet according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society their plight is desperate. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of the species. Dolphins hold a special place in our affections. We admire them in the sea and gaze at them on TV. They are a symbol of health and happiness. But behind the dolphin's smile is a bleak future. Their populations are declining at an unprecedented rate. Around the world, there are between three and five million dolphins. The average size is just over 20ft (6 metres). But today their numbers are less than one million. There are many reasons why. For starters, the food industry has overgrazed dolphins. One in five are now dependent on fishing for their livelihood. This puts them at high risk of injury or death from being hooked. They can even be shot by poachers. Scientists believe the dolphin may become extinct in the next 10 years. In addition, diseases like human immunodeficiency virus and bovine spongiform encephalopathy are wiping out dolphins. Some species have virtually no genes left to help them resist diseases such as bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), which threatens a third of their population in the Amazon. In Brazil, where BSE has taken hold, about 40% of all dolphins have the disease. The cause of this is a combination of climate change and pollution. The dolphins are pushed into the river by cattle or driven to the coastline by palm oil palm plantations. There they are washed up on the shore. As a result, their population is growing, which in turn means more conflict with humans. 
  
 Mark Simmonds is the presenter and

Over the past fifteen years my research has documented that for many online life and smartphone connections have got in the way of things that people feel are important. We're so busy communicating that we don't have time to think we don't have time to sit down and have a conversation. So the online world gets in the way of talking to people. We're trying to talk to people more because we are so addicted to talking to each other than we are to the real world. What we should really be talking about is ourselves.

We are constantly looking for others to talk to but the truth is that we don't talk to others as often as we talk to ourselves. The smartphone is an easy place to meet people, it can be found in almost every public place and it is very portable. We don't have to make a conscious effort to find someone to speak to but instead it comes automatically.   It makes it so easy to meet new people that we forget how important it is to have people to talk to. We don't even make an effort to look for someone we want to talk to so our friends aren't there when we need them.    I think it has gotten to the point where  we have so much electronic life that we no longer recognize that we need to spend time with ourselves. It takes us so long to process information and to get information that we no longer know how to look to ourselves. The Internet has become so important to us that we now have no time to think of the importance of sitting down and having a conversation with someone who we actually like or who we don't have to talk to. We're so busy finding ways to make our lives online that we forget how important the real world is.

As he was a King, I must obey the laws, if I wish to continue in this kingdom.' 'And you obey me?' inquired the queen. 'I obey you because your father was the king who ruled Denmark. I have no wish to be king of this one.' 'What!' interrupted the queen. 'I have no wish to be queen of any kingdom. Who am I to be in your opinion the real king?' 'As you are the queen, you are the only person in this kingdom who can be the true king,' replied Hamlet. The queen then asked, 'I have seen your mother, what did you think of her?' 'She was a great queen, but I never liked her. There were always too many people in the kingdom for my liking and she was selfish and unjust, for she wanted to rule this kingdom for her own sake, not that of her subjects.' The queen then asked Hamlet if he thought that he would be better off as king than he was as queen. 'Not really,' replied the prince. 'I am tired of being king. I would rather be queen of all the Denmark's than king of any one. For I have made a kingdom for my mother and my father, just as they would for themselves. Running a business in the countryside Five women talk about their experiences setting up a business in the countryside. A. ‘My customers are friends' says CHRISTINE HOGAN who runs a computer-aided design business with a turnover of over £200000 a year and four full-time employees. 'My husband and I moved out of London to the country when our children were small and I wanted work I could do at home. I was always quite handy with a needle and thread and, as a lady, it fitted in well with our surroundings. 'I went round to all the local craft shows and looked for an enterprise which would fit in with our lifestyle. 'After months of searching and applying for jobs, I decided to approach myself and ask my friends if they would like to give me a hand. They all said they would. 'It was the easiest job I've ever done and has given me a real sense of independence. When I've gone into town to shop I like to think that I have helped support my local community. 'I often feel like I'm saving an old woman's life by fixing her broken lamp.' A. 'The worst thing about running my own business is the early start time. I'm up at 6.00am each day but am usually home by 8.30am. There's no staff to help me get everything ready so it's the first thing I have to do in the morning. It takes me a couple of hours to set up the business as well as get everything ready for the day. 'It's also not easy to keep on top of everything. The business itself keeps me on my toes so I always have to check the finances and keep a careful eye on production. 'I sometimes find that I get to the office late. Charles Darwin (1809-1882) developed a revolutionary theory of evolution that transformed the way we understand the world and we see ourselves. In On the Origin of Species published in 1859 Darwin described the process of natural selection. The 'fittest' animals or plants - those with the characteristics best suited to their environment - are more likely to survive and reproduce. This process occurs as the population gets larger and larger, which leads to higher fitness. Eventually the fittest, or most genetically 'fit' animals, have evolved - and there you have it. The theory is now one of the best established scientific theories and there are countless articles and books devoted to its application to all aspects of society. It's widely believed to be a major influence on the development of human culture. A classic illustration of this is the many depictions of animals which are thought to have been drawn based on observation of Darwin himself - such as the elephant from the illustrations in The Origin of Species, and the turtle from The Descent of Man. But does it need to be? In this talk we'll examine a few key myths about evolution and the theory of natural selection. We'll examine the fact that most evolutionary theories were based on'sketch diagrams' to help students understand the concept, and then we'll look at some of the other explanations that have been suggested in the last few decades. And we'll examine the idea that'some' evolution is a consequence of selection, rather than the cause of evolution. It is worth emphasising that these are just theories based on observations and some studies have suggested that selection alone could not have led to the diversity in human behaviour. A full analysis of the idea is beyond the scope of this lecture, however. We'll also look at the controversy surrounding Darwin's comments about the morality of Darwinism and whether 'evolutionary science'

No Title We always went to Ireland in June. Ever since the four of us began to go on holidays together we had spent the first fortnight of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a large house by the sea not far from the village of Ardbeag. It was always very romantic and we spent the weeks building the most wonderful holiday. One year I woke up in the middle of the night, in the middle of my dreams, to the sound of a horse and cart running. I opened my eyes to discover a man running after it. We always found our horses in the grounds. We were soon able to settle down for the night. Once, on my birthday, my brothers went on a horse and cart ride round the grounds, down the hill, and back to the lodge for a cup of tea. I decided to stay behind and wait for them in the lodge. A few days later they brought up my birthday cake. But I couldn't eat it. I had been in the dreams for so long I was starting to see things. It was like the cakes weren't my own. I had no control over what was happening, except when I opened my eyes. As a result, I had a terrible headache all night long. I told my brothers that I was going to take the train back to London. We started our journey at four in the morning. We were due at the Dublin terminus at midnight. But when we arrived we found that the train had broken down. It was in the middle of the country, a few miles outside the city, and the police were closed off for the Easter weekend. We stood in the station for more than five hours. In the end we decided to walk, but only to the next train station

Going up the wall  Once climbers went to the mountains. Now a challenging climb can be had anywhere indoors or out. The crowd holds its breath. High above them on the climbing wall hanging upside down by the tips of two fingers is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. 

Climbing competitions are judged by a panel of judges and Lombard is facing off against 17 other top contenders. 
  
 But Lombard has the advantage of speed and experience. 
  
 His climbing skills are amazing. He is the second man in history to climb all 7 Summits - climbing each one at least twice and summiting the highest peak on every continent except Antarctica. 
  
 But Lombard has a reputation for an edge. He is also known for a vicious reputation. 
  
 He became known for his aggressive fighting style. He once knocked a fellow competitor from the air with a big punch. 
  
 Lombard's team-mate is Australian Mark Beaumont. He is considered the best ever climber on the World Cup circuit. He had to retire from competition early this year because of a hip injury but has now picked up his climb. 
  
 Beaumont said: "We're going up this wall a lot faster than Francois is going. We've just got to be able to find a way to catch him." 
  
 But Lombard has found another way to try and beat him - he's taking the lead in the race. 
  
 At the end of the final climb in 2009, Lombard was the world champion with a time of 22min 45sec.

It’s true - we’re all getting too big for our boots Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy when he left school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point - because Chris though still only fourteen was already almost two metres tall. His long legs were almost six feet tall. He looked like an Olympic gymnast. Now, at twenty-two, he’s still almost a foot taller than the average man. ‘I want to be the next big thing. I’m going to Hollywood.’ The problem is, he hasn’t landed a single part yet. He auditioned for one role. And that was the end of his acting career. Chris Greener is now a producer. He has written several films and has a television series on BBC1. His latest script, ‘Sink or Swim’, was shown on the BBC2 documentary series ‘Made in Britain’. It was made by a student crew from the University of Salford and starred Chris Greener, John Farrow and Tom Fletcher. The show was filmed in the summer of 2005 and was released to cinemas in the autumn. Chris spent the better part of the next two years trying to get the film accepted for the 2006 New York Film Festival - an achievement no one had done before. To get there, he had to convince more than 120 financiers that his film deserved to go to the Oscar ceremony. Unfortunately, Hollywood doesn’t think so - and that’s why he doesn’t know when he’ll hear a response from producers for ‘Sink or Swim’. But he doesn’t seem to mind too much. �

Gary and Me The restaurant owner John Moore writes about his relationship with his son Gary the famous TV chef. I believe everyone's given a chance in life. My son Gary was given his chance with cooking and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity I rushed over to look at the place. I was shocked to see it was in good order. When John Moore saw my son I knew he had found his man. I took John to my restaurant to meet my employees. It was a long day, but I knew John was right for my restaurant. Now if John can only find his way around London.... (continued) Gary lived with his mother and was doing pretty well as he continued to be the star of every cooking show. But he had a secret, which he wanted to keep from his family. Gary had a hidden talent he never told anyone because he believed it would ruin his chances at a life in the food industry. But that wasn't true, as it had already ruined his life, as he was a convicted drug dealer who spent his days in prison. But now he had another chance, thanks to a man who was ready to turn his life around. Gary had changed his life and started a new business selling meals to prisons, under the name Gary's Cafe. He had also changed his name. He had turned his old name into a new name, that was more professional. And then he had found a friend in John. They agreed that when they were released from prison, Gary would join John in his new venture. It was important to their relationship that both men helped others. They both knew what it was like to make little money and feel like they were stuck. But when they got out, they would do what it took to keep their families fed. Gary

Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch a 24-year-old from West Sussex. This is her second year as a chalet girl for St. Christopher's House, a four-star hotel in St. Moritz, Switzerland. This year, as in years before, she has done a great job of keeping the chalets and the people who stay in them happy. She is an attractive young woman. There is nothing particularly unusual about her. What sets her apart is her cheerful attitude. In her chalet she has two rooms – one for her dormitory and one for the room she spends most of her time in. There is even a little kitchen on her floor. The work she does is the same for both: she is in charge of tidying the dormitory and of the kitchen. The cooks come to her for advice. Her roommate is a 24-year-old man from London. He is a very good cook and the dormitory is kept in the best possible condition. But neither of them is a chalet girl and they are perfectly happy. One of their roommates is a 23-year-old woman from the Netherlands. She is a talented singer but she has other interests, too. There is a little pool outside the dormitory and she spends much of her time there singing. The other roommate is a 27-year-old man from England who speaks English and French well. He works in a small shop and lives in a house just outside the city of Saint Moritz. He also sings but is a terrible dancer.

In 1998 the world-class Moroccan athlete Hicham El Guerrouj broke the 1500-metres world record with a time of three minutes twenty-six seconds. Nearly fifteen years later nobody has beaten that time. Have we got to the human speed limit? Dr Frances Ashcroft Professor of Physiology at Oxford University explains the limits of the human body during a race.We all knew it: the human body is a strange beast. If it was a car, it would be a big engine, capable of great speeds, but without safety equipment or much oversight. If it were a machine, it would probably be the fastest, safest, and most efficient machine on the planet, and still might not be fast enough. If it was a living thing, it would probably be one of the slowest, if not the slowest creature in the universe, because all the cells would be asleep. And even those cells would sleep when they were tired.

I have always known that the body is a weird animal: I have always tried to stay healthy; the old “Eat, sleep, exercise” adage has served me well over the years. I have always known there are limits to how fast it can go (for example, even a 400-lb gorilla could not reach the speed of light when on all fours) and that they could not be exceeded (the limits have been set well before Einstein published his theory of relativity). But now, as a scientist and a physician, I am having trouble understanding how my body works. Why does it produce the incredible feats of endurance it does? Why does it make the amazing runs of the world-class athletes? When I try to understand my body’s limits, I am frustrated and confused. It seems so clear to me how the body works and what it will not tolerate, but

I'm always in a rush to finish shopping so I can start shopping again. So that's why I'm always behind!

Please give me a mail if you like my ideas. I want to hear from you.It's easy to forget that shopping is part of life, as well as eating and sleeping. However, sometimes we tend to forget the fact that we must think about what we want to buy, before rushing to the shops. The truth is that shopping can make you less healthy and it can also destroy some of your body's functions.

An eye for detail Artist Susan Shepherd is best known for her flower paintings and the large garden that surrounds her house is the source of many of her subjects. It is full of her favourite flowers most especially varieties of tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. The iridescent green-blue poppies often give a feeling of magic. The colours are very delicate and shimmer like fairy dust over the water in the garden. In the winter there is just a whisper of colour on the branches of the trees and over the rocks. Sometimes the water turns blue from the light on the grass. When the sun is shining the flowers are bright pink in the late morning as the sun hits the pink flowers before the water has a chance to reach the surface. When it does the pink water sparkles. The late afternoon is a very special time as the petals fall from the flower in a beautiful cloud. This is my favourite part of the day to photograph as the sun reaches the petals. If you live in London you should come and visit the garden. You will be delighted with the many beautiful flowers and will feel inspired by the colours and light. Flowering in London Susan Shepherd, Birdseye Gallery, (020 6235 4222, http://www.birdseyegallery.co.uk)
A view from the garden Looking across to the front of the house to the garden at Birdseye, London. It is full of flowers including poppies in the summer, tulips in the winter. Susan Shepherd, Birdseye Gallery, (020 6235 4222, http://www.birdseyegallery.co.uk)
A tulip is in bloom, London, Susan Shepherd, Garden at Birdseye

Food for all We proudly present our own hand-picked special selection of the very best cookbook titles now on offer. A. Ask anyone to think of a famous TV cook and writer and it's frequently Delia Smith's name that comes to mind. Delia was a star of the BBC's "The Great British Bake Off" from 1996-2007, where she was an established name as well as an ardent cookbook writer. As the show went on to become the UK's longest-running cooking show, Smith started publishing her recipes in the early 2000s. The title "Delia Smith: 100 Best Recipes" was a bestseller and a BBC cookbook of the same name followed in 2010. Smith has gone on to write several cookbooks and is currently publishing one every year or so. These have been well received on a widespread level in both the UK and US, and Delia is still the number one selling cookbook author in the UK. (More than double the number of her second place rival Julia Child, according to a 2007 BBC survey.) The original "100 Best Recipes" also spawned numerous offshoots, with the most popular being "100 Best Bakes," "100 Best Fries" and "100 Best Salad." These have sold around 10 million copies to date, while the more recent "100 Best Classics," and "100 Best Flavors" have also become bestsellers, in the UK and US respectively. There is also "Delia's Master Chef" series, with series 1-10 currently in production. One series, "Delia's Master Chef: Cook and Bake," also produced a popular television series in the US, with series 1-8 released on DVD in 2012. A book of the

Buckley's four o'clock press conference did not come on the early evening news. Jake laughed when first the national TV channels and then Memphis then Jackson then Ripelo ended their broadcasts with no news about the Hailey trial and no pictures of Buckley on the screen. At ten Jake and his wife Carla lay in the dark on the sofa waiting for the news. Carla kept repeating over and over to Jake: "You don't understand! Hailey is in the slammer!" Jake was thinking that nothing was more boring than the silence. He remembered his parents telling him many times when he was a young child: "Don't talk so much, so nobody will talk back to you." Now he was sure that this rule applied to radio! He was tired and it was time to sleep. At eleven the phone rang. A voice said: "Hello, this is the news. What news has happened?" "Nothing!" Jake said. But in this case he was wrong. Two minutes later the television news came on with a full story about the Hailey verdict. Five minutes later Jake's TV turned on again with news about the tragic death of a young musician named Jimi. Then he realized that all of this news was part of the same story. He felt even more bored. At twelve the phone rang. He opened the door to see the television. Five minutes ago it showed two women talking about the Hailey verdict. A tearful young woman was looking down at the floor and sobbing uncontrollably. Behind them was a very bored policeman. "What are you staring at?" Jake asked. The policeman said: "I don't know what you are talking about. Do you have the latest news?" "Yes, I have the latest news," said Jake, annoyed by the police officer's interruption. Jake heard a phone ringing on the wall

Week after week British tabloid newspapers carry pictures which intrude into people’s privacy and break the newspaper editors’ code of practice. Although pop stars do pose for paparazzi on occasion this is not typical. More usually great damage is done to [line 6: beginning] individuals in the public eye when they see their most [line 6: end] private moments captured on the front page.
The statement is valid.
As well as being a well-known tabloid newspaper the News of the World is also, as it is widely held, the British tabloid press, which was founded, as a rival to The Sun which was founded in 1821, a little earlier. Both have always claimed to be more “transparent” than the other.
But how does one separate the tabloid press from the true tabloid press in a sea of paparazzi shots? That question can be asked in terms of journalistic ethics as well as personal ethics.
The tabloids are run by newspaper editors who, according to their editorial guidelines, are to keep their news gathering activities and reporting activities to a minimum.
This is not always done, but often it is not done to the extent that some photographs that appear in the tabloids or are on the web could be considered as “confidential” (they are not publicly available on the web). The editors of the newspapers that publish the tabloids have an understanding between themselves to publish only those images that are not yet publicly available.
I am aware that sometimes there are photographs of celebrities that are published in their private life which could only be published in private and which are not published on any other news media other than their tabloids. For example, a photograph of Jennifer Lawrence and Leonardo DiCaprio kissing in the garden of Jennifer Lawrence’s parents home might only have been published in one tabloid newspaper, but could

So Uncle Oscar signed the agreement and Paul's mother received the whole five thousand. Then something very strange happened. The voices in the house suddenly went mad: there were thousands of them. There was new furniture and Paul had a teacher. He was really going to Eton his father's school in the following autumn. The five thousand was supposed to cover everything. Paul and Oscar did not speak for several weeks, then they met again and Paul explained everything. Oscar was not angry at all; the children were not only going to go to Eton, but to be the best they could. He had taken them to the best private tutor and the result was spectacular: Paul had scored a 9 on a new exam at Eton and he was going to be captain next year. That was his only chance. He told his mother he wanted to get married, but his father had said that Oscar's mother must attend the wedding only to act as a best man. But that was enough for Oscar. He was delighted with his son, who had become a great man. He would never have it any other way. Who is the thief?The fact is that it was actually Paul's father who signed the agreement, not Uncle Oscar. Paul's father had promised Oscar to provide for him a suitable school, one which is considered to be the most prestigious in England. As a reward, he was to be able to send his son to Eton. But the very next day, Paul's father returned from London with a whole different idea.

As the result of an accident, Paul had lost his job as a taxi driver. He was therefore in a terrible situation: to support his family, he would have to sell off his family home and live off the money his father had promised him. Paul's father

Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl’s work is never done Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch a 24-year-old from West Sussex. “The first year I had no idea what I was doing. I was trying to learn the language! This year I feel I’ve got my feet on the ground,” she says. This year she is in charge of all the catering at the B&B in the French alps – for the three chalet owners and 40 guests. “Last year it was all me, and I made a really good success of it. I do all the baking – breads, buns, cakes. I like to make a good impression on my guests,” says Sarah. Her father is English and her mother is French, so she has a bilingual background from a young age. “My mum likes to bake, so that was always part of my family’s life. But my dad’s in charge of the restaurant in Brighton so I have to manage that in here,” she laughs. For her parents, the holiday-making season is a happy one. “When we went to Switzerland and France, the weather wasn’t as bad as it can be now – but when we get the first snow in Brighton you realise how cold it is in winter. It’s all about having that sense of adventure – which is what we’re all doing on holiday. It’s great that it’s not all about going to a big resort or to some fancy hotel. Everyone can stay in

The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport Suzie Ellis went to meet England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is captain of England's netball team. When I met her she'd had a typical day for the weeks leading up to next month's World Championships: a day's teaching at a local school followed by a training session in the local supermarket car park. The team had recently returned from a pre-season tour to China. Their aim was to stay fit and in shape for the forthcoming World Championship, to be played next month in South Africa. The team is made up of players from other sports who are interested in playing netball. For many it is their first experience of netball and they're looking forward to using their new-found skills. For some they've been playing for nearly 30 years, they've all won bronze and silver medals. "As well as having fantastic ability, netballers are hard working and committed," explains captain Slowinski. "We want to win a medal at the World Championships. "We don't just play for fun. It's our job to represent our country and the sport." Netballers make excellent captaincy candidates. They're experienced, they understand their role and the impact it has in the team's performance, and they have the right attitude. In Suzie Ellis, I met someone who was committed to her sport, her team-mates, and the country that supported her. The Netball Captain "I started playing netball in my mid-teens, it was an after school activity at a local community centre," explains Slowinski. "My partner and I were playing together so that was a great way to meet people." Slowinski's journey into the sport, however, didn't just happen. "When I started playing, I was a bit nervous and I had no idea what was

ICE SKATING Ice skating has a history of thousands of years. Archaeologists have discovered skates made from animal bone. It seems that bone skates were used until the introduction of iron into Scandinavia about the year 200 AD. Among the Scandinavian upper classes skating was seen as an essential skill. The first skates, made out of wood, are known to have been made during the time of the Viking period. Around the year 1000 a group of Danish skaters set out on a voyage to the New World. They called it the “Denmark of the Indies”. They sailed from Copenhagen to New Orleans. Today it is thought that most of the skaters today are from Denmark. As time passed, the popularity of skating declined. The first modern skates made of iron, in the form of iron skates, was used on ice in the 19th century. In the early 20th century the interest in ice skating returned to Scandinavia. There has been a strong demand for skates ever since. There are many manufacturers, especially in Scandinavia, who make all kinds of wooden skates. For those who prefer a softer and more flexible style of skating, steel skates are often used. The skates in the metal shop are not made from metal but rather from alloy. Skates made of iron are more hard and can do their work even without a handle or grips. Skate shops can provide skates for various levels of skaters, from novice to professional. There is also a wide variety of brands. If you are interested in purchasing a skates in Europe, it may be worthwhile to visit a few different shops. At a shop, you can look at different brands and prices. It is also possible to buy a used or new skates online.

The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport Suzie Ellis went to meet England’s netball captain. Kendra Slawinski is captain of England's netball team. When I met her she'd had a typical day for the weeks leading up to next month's World Championships: a day's teaching at a local school followed by a training session in the local supermarket car park. The women's sport, once so frowned upon, has found huge public support, especially in the last few years. The England captain, Kendra Slawinski, a 34-year-old former student of the University of Sheffield, is passionate about women's sport. "If we had 100,000 young girls coming through our doors, women's sport would be a vital part of their lives," she says. Last month, Slawinski was one of four captains chosen to represent the British women's squad in the 2016 European Championship. The tournament is in Spain in September and Slawinski, a former England squad member and current coaching staff member, will be her country's captain. "I'm lucky enough to be a squad captain," she explains. "It's a great honour." But in a sport where gender is still highly problematic, Slawinski knows the challenge ahead. "Women have the lowest participation rates in the team. It's something I have to get our girls to think about, and as captains, I have to talk to them about." The squad will face off against Spain, Germany and France. "It's a tough group," she says. "We're in good shape, though, but we want to keep it that way." She admits that the team's success is not driven by players. "We're lucky to have two or three superstars, and a lot of great players in our team, but it's the strength of the team as a whole

In the school: swims at least three times a week. Student body vice-president.

First of all, it would give you a great excuse to go to the gym and have a few body-weight exercises.  
Secondly, it would give you a lot of self-confidence. 
Thirdly, you'd have a great chance of meeting someone that might like the same kind of sport as you. 

Here are some suggestions on how to get it done.

Swim in the morning or in the afternoon if it's warm.
Get a bike and try to find an urban cycling path for running in your town or country.
Take a long bike ride to train.
Run/walk when it's not too cold.I'd definitely work on your strength/body conditioning!
You could also join a local sports club, and then you don't have to be around "dirtbags" or "douchebags" or people that are going to tell you to "get in shape."

Trying to get published? If you are wondering where to send your story our expert Margaret Stubbs is here with the advice you need. Readers of this magazine often write in saying 'I have written this story / book. It needs publishing. What should I do?' Our expert, Margaret Stubbs is an independent editor, based in London. She has edited the magazine for more than five years and has an excellent record of finding publishers for writers. Here she gives her advice. 
I have a book proposal which I am now getting to grips with. I have been accepted by a publishers for my book on British art called British Design. I have some research work to do, but I know what they want and how they expect it to look. I am worried that the style I want will clash with the publisher. It's not for them to tell me what I should or should not do, but rather to advise me on how to go about making my book look good. Are there any specific things I should do? And if so, what should I avoid? And also what should I include to make it sound like a full book and not just a pamphlet?First of all, it sounds as though you have done some research. You have identified a topic and a market that you are interested in writing about. Good.
Now the question is, will your writing about the topic of British Design satisfy the requirements of the publisher? Will you be able to provide a good product that meets those needs? 
The most important thing is to make sure that the book is good quality. If you can do this, then any publisher will happily take on the task. However, if you make a bad copy

In the weeks before the end of the tax year everyone in the firm was especially busy. With no wife to go home to Mitch worked later than anyone else. Besides he had extra work to do. One night at three in the morning he unlocked Avery's office on the fourth floor with one of the keys Abby had given him. On the desk there was a map of the firm, one wall was taken up by a large shelf with many books on taxes. Avery had spent many years working at the firm and as Mitch suspected he kept his work place spotless. Avery's office was dark as he put the map on the wall and put the desk open on the top of the shelf. "Avery, come here. We're going to talk business." Avery turned and looked at Mitch. "What's your business?" "I'm gonna get that job with that IRS man. It's payin' too good to pass up." "Why do you want to work for him?" "If I do it, then you'll have an opening." "Maybe." "I know who'll fill your spot." Mitch closed the door on Avery's office. "Who?" "My man Chuck has been lookin' all over for that opening. He's good at his job. I told you he can work after my shift ends." "And you know you're the one who's getting paid more?" "I know. And he's gonna take care of everything from now on." Mitch was glad to have a backup plan. "So, who is it?" Who can fill Chuck's spot?Chuck was shocked. He'd spent his entire life at the firm. All of his brothers and sisters were also employees. Chuck went outside to talk to Mitch.

"No one's replacein' me."

Film Critic Mark Adams looks back over the last ten years of his work as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for The Front Page was my first proper job. Before then I had done bits of reviewing - novels for other newspapers films for a magazine and anything I was asked to do for the radio. That all led to writing for The Front Page. Back then I started out by reviewing, but quickly moved to writing feature film reports. A year later we became a film blog in which I now review films for The Front Page. I began reviewing independently, but found that it was getting harder and harder to attract the attention of film magazines (especially ones that were focused on new movies). Then, in 2006, we came up with the idea of a film blog, and the rest is history. The blog has grown from a one person operation to a group of six individuals all of whom contribute their opinion and write about the films we watch on a weekly basis.
If you have never heard of The Front Page, it is a local daily newspaper. I reviewed for them for a year and a half and have fond memories of the time spent there. Most recently I was writing feature film reviews for them, but this has now come to an end as of today. It will always be a part of my memory, but now I have other things to do. The blog will be running in its place.
What is it about reviews that make them so enjoyable? When you are done you can sit back and reflect upon what a review meant to you, what you thought about the film itself and what you liked or disliked about it. In a way it is also like a conversation with someone you respect or just someone you would like to know better, so it is also an ideal way to spend an

Favourite places Bruce I don't like landscapes which are completely untamed. It's the human element which is important to me. It's the same when I travel abroad. Lovely villages with old temples attract me not empty deserts. When I was eight I went away to school in England and on Saturdays I would cycle to the village of Lastingham in its lovely valley. It felt very safe being in the middle of a village. I spent a week there riding my bike on its wide road and admiring all the different kinds of cows. One particular cow with its shiny belly fascinated me. I never forgot it. When I was eight years old I decided I wanted a little cow like it. My mother took me to the dairy at the farm to check the cows and when we found her, she bought her for me. I was very happy. The cow became part of my family. It's so beautiful and gentle and we loved her so much! Favourite place Bruce is the place that I am best able to describe. When I am in the country and I think of something, I go to the place in my mind and it's there forever. I was talking to a friend the other day and I told him that the place in my mind is the place which I always go to when I think of something. It was the same with my dog when I was little. When I was a child I would run with him everywhere in the countryside. The only thing which ever bothered me was the fact that when we went up a steep hill my dog would fall down and I had to pick him up. Then there is a funny memory from when I was seven. We were out running in the field and suddenly I tripped on a branch. It was difficult because the branches were wet but I managed to get him back up. I wasn't sure if

'Archie' said Mrs Easterbrook to her husband 'listen to this.' Colonel Easterbrook paid no attention. He was busy reading The Times. 'These reporters know nothing about India' he said. 'Nothing! If they did they wouldn't write such rubbish.' 'Yes I know' said his wife. 'Archie do listen. A murder is announced and will take place on Friday October 29th at Little Paddocks at 6.30 p.m. We want Archie to find out who the murderer is, what sort of a apron the man wears and if it had a collar or buttons.' What is the answer?The murder is announced on a Friday, and it will take place at Little Paddocks on October 29th at 6:30 p.m. We want Archie to find out who the murderer is, what sort of a apron the murderer wears and if it has a collar or buttons.
The only evidence necessary is Archie’s note that he found on the murderer, and his notes.
Archie was able to narrow down the possible apron maker from a number of aunts and uncles. The aunts had been to Little Paddocks before. The uncle had not.
Archie was able to narrow down the aunts from two of them, so he had to find the uncle. 
Archie arrived at Little Paddocks on the Friday. He didn’t find out anything except the apron was called a ‘jumper,’ but the murderer wore a baseball cap with a logo on it. So he found his uncle. He found the uncle outside his house, but he said he wouldn’t be home for dinner. He said he would be back in a day. The uncle’s wife and daughter were also there. Careers Advice You're not happy in your job at the moment but you don't know how to change? Kitty Doherty gives some good advice. The answer for more and more people who want to change their job is to turn to a careers adviser. You will be asked to write a brief history of yourself and then sit through a number of tests known as 'psychometrics'. These tests will measure your aptitude for certain skills. In addition you will have some interviews with possible employers and you will receive some advice on what you should do next. After you have written your resumé and some of your experiences in this field you will go through a selection process. Here a lot of people who have decided to quit their job are re-assessed. They may be interviewed for an alternative position which is less stressful. You should contact this scheme immediately so that they can assess you.

IN HOT WATER Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends as much time as she can at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel Mills teaches and does research into marine geochemistry which means she studies the chemical processes happening in the sea. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. One of her students is Peter who is an expert on the chemistry of sea water. Rachel gets into difficulty with Peter when he is involved with an experiment that has very dangerous results. In this episode Rachel is sent to a penal colony in The Canary Islands to help Peter investigate the contamination of sea water in a well. Peter and Rachel come into contact with the Spanish captain Jose Luis who has taken over the operations of the penal colony. There are other scientists working in the colony but they are more interested in working with animals. When Rachel starts to work with sea animals she is disturbed by a number of problems.

Kowloon Walled City had no wall around it. Standing apart from the neighbouring buildings it rose to fourteen floors-buildings with more buildings piled on top. Legally it belonged to the People's Republic of China a part of the colony that was never British. In fact neither Chinese nor British law had effect there. The residents simply ignored both.
When people moved in they didn't live as if they were permanently living under the Chinese government. And when the People's Republic of China closed the port and airport leaving only the roads that had been built and left the building owners in complete control they also abandoned their laws and customs.
The people in Kowloon were able to negotiate with the locals on a daily basis. They came to an agreement that meant the owners of the houses that were higher than fifteen floors were willing to let the local people live there.
Kowloon had a population of roughly 1 million people. They worked on four different building types, the middle class owned three, the working class bought one and the lower class owned the other.
That last type of dwelling was a one bedroom apartment. Living on the top three floors they had a bedroom with a queen bed and a living room and kitchen with a kitchen sink and table. On the top floor they had a bathroom with a shower. Toilet paper and toilet paper rolls were not provided. A small kitchen sink would do and that was it. Everything was provided for them by the government. A landlord would pay the owner a monthly rent of four hundred and fifty dollars and one person was a tenant. They owned their own house and did not have to worry about paying rent or buying supplies and paying someone to fix their plumbing.
The Chinese gave the local people control of the area and money to live there. The Chinese owners of

WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE When you first enter the Model Village it is hard to imagine that a few short years ago this was a piece of waste ground flat and completely overgrown with brambles. For years it had been considered a worthless piece of land.
We had recently received permission from the Mayor of York, Mr. Gordon Gill, to clear and transform this area for public open space so that we could develop it to a model community for our community.
During the months that followed we built a village centre building for meetings and to show other local groups how to take up building with young people.
We built the centre of the village with local suppliers; using their materials and the materials we had saved from previous buildings.
This was not only to make the project more local, but also to build some skills amongst our young people. We have built this model village with a lot of help from our local community. We thank everyone for all of their help.
There are still more work to be done but we are very excited to be working in this new project.
On the 2nd August we will have our first meeting. This is at 2pm in the village hall.
If anyone is keen on becoming involved there will be a recruitment drive.
There will be a brief introduction by the Village Stewards and a talk from the community development officer.
Please drop in if you would like more information on how you can get involved.
We thank everyone for their support.
Please see the following links for further information:
http://www.yorkcouncil.gov.uk/whats-on/york-village-center/york-council-residual-community-

Variations on a Theme If you're thinking of taking children to a theme park there are dozens to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to test the best. Fun Island - The Burns family Last year we went to a huge theme park in the US and we thought that Fun Island might seem dull by comparison. But it was everything the Americans failed to be. This year it was the opposite - a fantastic day out. The Burns family have been to Disneyworld and Disneyland, but had never set foot in a theme park before. There was a lot of excitement in the camp before our trip - we knew that it would have a huge and spectacular water park where we could zip through the water and have the chance of doing a barrel roll. The water park is very big, with huge waterslides, so it's not a small and family friendly park. But it's not as big as most theme parks - even though it has a great deal of equipment for kids. As well as a huge water park there's an indoor theme park, a food court and an outdoor food court where you can have pizza delivered to the park. We had a fantastic day and we got to meet a very cute little boy called Charlie - his Dad said that he was always smiling and asking us to take him for rides. We were lucky to have got tickets to the end of the day for £4.95 a go. We booked tickets well in advance so it wasn't expensive - although my boys were still fidgeting all day. We had a £9.95 lunch and an entry to the park plus £2 per person per day parking which was cheaper than expected and we didn't have to queue - just a quick tap on the card. Charlie was very well behaved and enjoyed the rides. He spent the

Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the full to tell us how they do it. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I think it's excitement. I've got to be doing something that's a challenge. If I'm absorbing something new and learning I get tremendous energy. If I'm bored or tired, I've got to do something else. If I'm not motivated at all, I've got to figure out why I'm not motivated.' There is no time for boredom to interfere with your work. You've got to make your work the top of your list at all times. I get motivated by something as simple as having a pen with me. Sometimes it's a pen because I'm running late or I'm having dinner with my friends and I want to be able to write something right away. Sometimes I have a pen because there is a new idea that's been staring at me for the past few hours and I want to write it right away. Then I have a pen to do that. 'I try to be a good listener to other people. If I've got questions or problems at work or things to talk about, I try to listen to other people and try to help them solve their problems if I can. I also try to make sure that I'm not too uptight about what I'm going to say in front of other people, because in the end, it's not about how I look or what I wear or what color my tie is. It's about doing something that really matters, so I want to be as relaxed as I can be. 'I've got my morning coffee and I always wear clothing that makes me feel good, but if I were to sit down and choose clothes, I'd probably pick a shirt that says

Confident people what's their secret? Confident people may look as though they were born that way but most will tell you that it's a skill they've learned because they had to. Nina Hathway asks five people how they did it. A Jenny When I left school I was very shy and I always thought I'd stay that way. I was very small for a girl and I didn't wear make-up as much as other kids. My dad would take me to the makeup booth and it would just be me and the makeup artists. They would do some tests on me and they said I have quite a pretty face but I just seemed really shy. I'm so glad they gave me that opportunity to be able to do that. Jenny's Dad had taken her to the makeup booth before. He used to take her to get a little make-up when she was young but she said she never wanted to have to do that again. It was quite a big deal for her when they came to do her makeup for the first time. She had really, really big nerves. There were three other girls who had been there before but she had the highest anxiety. She didn't have her sister there because she would never be as nervous as her. She had her sister, Lizzie, there with her. Lizzie was in the same makeup booth but she was a little bit skinnier. Nina was in the makeup booth and her sister was waiting outside. She noticed that Lizzie was skinnier than Nina was. Nina was not used to seeing Lizzie with more weight and she was a bit nervous about looking fat next to her. Nina had an awful time that day. When the make-up woman was finished, she showed her the mirror and told her to look at herself and try to feel

Trills and bills If there's one thing guaranteed to send tears running down your cheeks it's the sight of a brilliant child collecting a medal. Julia Gregson asked three young stars and their mothers to describe some of the pleasures and pains of their lives. A. Annika Reeder 15 won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. "In my time I competed at the Olympics and I did it at the Commonwealth Games and at the World Championships," she says. "It was a very different experience; it was a wonderful experience but it was very draining." There's no doubt her success has made her a world star, but "sometimes you'd feel quite lonely, as a youngster you're thinking 'Oh, but I'm not good enough,'" says Rebecca Bellis, 24, who competed at the Olympics in London and won a gold medal in triathlon. "You look around and you're like 'Am I really any good?' and you're thinking 'Oh my god, what am I doing wrong?'" Rebecca now lives in Manchester, where she works in an engineering company and trains with a local club. She won a silver medal at the Commonwealth Games in 2012. Sarah Hillyer, 16, became a world champion this year when she triumphed in the under-17 women's 5,000m race. "There were a lot of people around. And they're cheering, and then you're just thinking 'They can hear me, can't they? I'm running through this course - why can't they hear me?'" She spends her free time doing charity events, but says training for triathlon has been a "really hard year in terms of my mental health and mental strength, because I want to do something physically and then get into a good mental frame and have a good run. My line of work Four people talk about their jobs. Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser Science Museum I'm responsible for putting temporary exhibitions together. This includes planning and designing the exhibition and promoting it. I take on lots of new jobs and I'm constantly learning more about my craft. I like working as I can use my experience in different ways. I have a knack for managing all aspects of a job at the same time, as well as getting the most out of people. Anne - Curatorial Assistant, Natural History Museum I work alongside the expert curators to make sure that their collections have the most up-to-date information possible. I like to think that I can think fast and solve problems in any situation and it's a good way to get my brain working. I do well when I'm not sure what to do. My strengths lie within people skills as well as in being able to do many jobs at once. I like the ability to have to deal with lots of different situations at the same time. I enjoy doing everything. I get great satisfaction from completing a collection and helping others do the same. I can be hardworking and reliable but also fun. Richard - Curatorial Assistant, Natural History Museum I work alongside the experts to make sure that their collections have the most up-to-date information possible. I am responsible for finding and preparing the collection for the show. I can organise volunteers and keep the show running on time. My strengths lie within my analytical thinking and ability to work with a diverse range of people. I can be hardworking and reliable but also fun. Richard loves working with large collections and he has a great instinct for how to organize them for shows

The kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher: a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and riversfeeding on fish. Old trees overhang the stream half shading shallow water. Soft greens mud browns and the many different yellows of sunlight are the main colours as soft as the sounds of water in the breeze. There is always a yellow heron perched by the stream side, but more often it is a heron or heron and some sort of duck that take their afternoon repose under the tall branches. It makes a soft humming noise as it takes it's refreshment before starting the long journey back home to its den. There is often a heron over the stream too. Charlie enjoys capturing this special wildlife of his. It really is the best part of his day. Charlie James's work has been featured in many magazines and newspapers, including Wildlife Photographer of the Year and on the cover of LIFE magazine. He has worked for the BBC as well as numerous magazines and newspapers. You can find more of his beautiful birds at the site www.charliajames.co.uk.
You can find more of Charlie's work at his website: http://www.charlieajames.co.uk/ (in English only).

There's no name for it either but the photo I see above looks to me like a kingfisher.
