Studio Audiences What's it like to be in the audience when a television programme is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Like technical difficultiesstudio audiences are just another common feature of television lifeand yet to many of us they remain a mystery. Watching them getting excited on game shows for example we sit back and ask ourselves - just who are these people? And then they look at us and laugh at our obvious ignorance. For some it's simply part of the enjoyment of the programme itself. I for one can't stand being sat in a back row! I really do enjoy watching other people's reactions, as long as there are no technical difficulties! For Cosmo we were lucky to have a good studio audience for this episode of The National Lottery's Big Millions. They were quite enthusiastic when we started with our intro. Then the show opened with them cheering when a contestant won the Big One! They knew it was going to be some time before we could reveal the winners. The show opened and we announced that the four players had already decided to keep their tickets, but the players didn't have an announcement to make at the moment. We asked them to wait a bit while we made our announcement, but they seemed rather bored to be waiting. So I just told them that the announcement had to come first. Their reactions were hilarious, particularly the woman who was a bit nervous. I think the players were just relieved to have their money back and they all started to talk about their dreams. The one player had two! It's amazing how life can turn on a dime! At the end of the show when I showed them the winning numbers they were so happy I could see their faces. They also thanked me for the introduction. I have to admit I was very excited about this show and as soon as it started I couldn't control myself. I

It’s true - we’re all getting too big for our boots Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy when he left school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point - because Chris though still only fourteen was already almost two metres tall. Chris’ father Chris had a reputation as an adventurous sportsman with a quick temper. The family was from Croydon in south London. Like all great sportsmen they grew up watching football and they were not surprised when, aged just fourteen, Chris was signed by Arsenal. He was a talented footballer but he had a huge appetite for trouble too and quickly began to get embroiled in several incidents on and off the pitch. In September 1974, Chris and his Arsenal teammate John Grogan went AWOL from the training ground and never returned to the club. John got arrested for “causing a disturbance”. In the next few years Chris was involved in more minor skirmishes with fans, but was still generally accepted by the local community. However, when he was twenty-three he became embroiled in a nasty row with a local resident called Gary Collins. Chris had been drinking on a night out and accidentally knocked a man unconscious with a punch he believed to be a harmless bouncy ball. Gary was upset about the attack and began a campaign of harassment and vandalism. When Chris tried to stop the vandalism, the man became more aggressive. Things went on for several months but, in October 1977, Chris finally had enough. He returned to his home in London and decided to take action against Gary. After several weeks, he borrowed a hammer and took on his enemy. He knocked out Gary to the extent that he needed five stitches in his eyebrow to close the wounds. Gary went to prison.

In April 1919 the British rulers in India decided to put down protests in the city of Amritsar. As people gathered in the public garden during the festival of Vaisakhi a British general ordered his soldiers to block the exits and shoot into the crowd. As well as thousands of injuries there were hundreds of deaths. The massacre in Amritsar has become known as the Golden Jubilee massacre. In the following years the British authorities tried to cover up the incident and the official death toll was not released until 1952. The number of people that actually died in this incident, including women and children, was not included in the official tally of deaths and injuries.

It was widely believed by British authorities that the actual death toll was over 1500. After the official death toll was released in 1952 British authorities released the official death toll of 500. This was a high number of deaths but was not as high as the death toll previously believed and there was the possibility that there were people that had died but were never recorded as such. It is now believed that British authorities in India deliberately covered up the mass killings in Amritsar during the Golden Jubilee massacre in order to prevent public unrest and unrest in the country.

This incident has had a significant impact on Indian history and public opinion in the coming years. The killings of people in Amritsar resulted in riots in the state of Punjab and further unrest. British officials had also hoped that people would remain in their homes during the Golden Jubilee celebrations. This is clearly not the case as many people took to the streets to protest against the British rule, with some riots taking place in the state of Punjab. In the coming years it is likely that the Golden Jubilee massacre will have a significant impact on political and social relations in the British Indian Empire

GM's clever EN-V concept is a two-wheeled two-seater solution to urban transport. Telegraph Motoring's Mike Rutherford has a preview and takes it for a spin. That's because of the nature of the EN-V. Last week I drove one of these though it was more like flying a small plane than driving. The car was so light that it almost felt weightless.
The EN-V will go well with some sports cars. It's very lightweight and the styling is very similar to the Bentley Continental GT Sport.
There are four wheels, not four wheels and two tires, and so there's less than 50 pounds (22.6 kilos) per wheel for acceleration and cruising.
The interior has a very similar look to a Bentley Continental GT, with a carbon fiber bucket seats and dashboard. They're also very similar to the seats on the Lamborghini Countach, though I found the seats in my Lambo to be more comfortable.
The only real difference is in the front seats. There are bucket seats for a driver, an emergency front seat passenger, and a seat in front for the driver with a USB port.
There's also a large central storage pocket for your phones and tablets.
The EN-V uses a fuel cell power plant in its battery. There are two fuel cells in the vehicle and these power both of the front wheels. The fuel cells are connected to a battery pack.
You'll probably find a more detailed review and a video of the vehicle in the gallery.

On the rails Five celebrities tell Andrew Morgan their favourite memories of railway journeys. A Andrea Thompson - Newsreader I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to get back there as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast which crosses the border with Italy. You can really feel the sun on your face and the sea rolling into your arms as you ride. The train is slow, but its history and scenery makes up for that in my eyes. The conductor is so excited that he announces we're a bit past St Tropez on our way to Bordeaux, and we can smell all the perfume of the shops along the coast. The journey along the coast is so beautiful, and you can really feel the breeze on your face as the train moves along the sea. The conductor announces we're now in the town of St Nazaire, and that's when I find out about the great wine tasting that happens here. It's a real treat, with French winemakers going around tasting each other's wine. It's a great way to enjoy the scenery and the wine of France. Andrew Morgan, ITV News, 2005.

What would happen to our planet if humans were to suddenly disappear? This is the basic hypothesis behind Alan Weisman's book The World Without Us. Weisman examines how long it would take for humankind's mark on Earth to disappear. In one chapter there is an analysis of how New York would survive if there were no humans to take care of it. It would still be the financial center of the United States, but the streets would be empty.
In chapter 4 Weisman focuses on the ecological repercussions of our actions, and he looks at how far society has come in terms of its ability to affect the natural world. This book offers an interesting perspective on what it would be like to live without humans, and the implications of our lack of impact on the planet.
The book isn't exactly easy to get into, although it is an interesting read. The author writes in the "introduction" that he was thinking a lot about what he had just read, when in fact he had just read it and felt it was important to express.
The most interesting aspect of the book is the discussion of how the population control movement has affected societies. The World Without Us is an interesting read, but I would suggest avoiding the first few chapters if at all possible.
In an interesting chapter Weisman looks at two countries which attempt to control their population, the tiny, and seemingly closed community of Tzahal and the larger, much larger Germany. In Tzahal the inhabitants choose a simple life and avoid the modern world. They also do not have children, and many women in this community do not breastfeed. In Germany, Germany offers more freedom in the form of more education, more freedoms in the form of more choice, more choice in the form of more access to healthcare and more access to food. Living in the valley We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first realised the dangers that could exist in the surrounding hills and threaten our very survival. It was the year when the storms came early before the calendar even hinted at winter even before November was out. We have always been accustomed to living in the valley, where water is scarce, but this was the most dangerous season for us. That was the season when heavy rains washed away our fields; that was the season when the rivers overflowed. This season we lost two thousand trees that had stood on the hillsides for three thousand years and when they fell, the hills could not hold their weight. It was the season when the rivers could not be crossed without boats, even when it was a season when a heavy wave could be felt and the waters of the river could be seen to foam. We had watched as our fields turned to mud; we could see the roots and branches of the trees in our backyard. We looked at our barren fields and saw only mud. We could not see the river. The water had dried up the river, which was the only way we knew of to cross the river and get across the valley. When our house got swept away, we knew that we had to cross the river to escape. We walked across the mud fields which was all we had left when we fled the valley. We walked and walked in that miserable night and in the morning we had walked all the way to Kedarnath. We started the long trek in the dark and we all woke up at seven in the morning. We had made it. We had crossed over and survived. It was a sad day. Miss Rita Cohen a tiny pale-skinned girl who looked half the age of Seymour's daughter Marie but claimed to be some six years older came to his facto1y one day. She was dressed in overalls and ugly big shoes and a bush of wiry hair framed her pretty face. "Miss" Cohen asked him to dance. "Yes" Seymour responded, but then changed his mind. "Can't you afford a ballroom?" he said, "Why don't you go back to the country and I'll buy you a nice ballroom. If you're ever in Paris, I'll show you the most elegant room in all Paris." So Seymour went back to his flat and had a long conversation with his wife. He took out a photograph from his wallet and showed it to her. Then he said to her, "This is what I've been planning. And there's another girl as well - Marie. If you have a good time, if you know any of these girls, they'd like to dance with you - and I might even arrange to see them again. My wife says I'm going too far - but she doesn't mind. I want to see her again - if I'm lucky." Seymour was delighted with himself and was planning to write a letter to Marie that night. However, before he could finish the letter to Marie, he was disturbed by an angry voice. The telephone rang and Seymour answered it, but the caller didn't say any names. "You're ruining everything," he shouted, "and I hate you!" Seymour turned and ran to the cellar. There he found that the caller was in fact Marie. Ned Ingham: Dress Designer Ned Ingham makes dreamy romantic wedding dresses. 'People would do well to avoid the traditional rather stiff dresses and the 'frilly' look in favour of much simpler styles' he explains. 'And the wedding cake needs something a little more sophisticated for today's generation.' Other dresses in the new catalogue feature tulle, lace or beading. 'A dress can be as pretty and elegant as silk or lace if the right accessories are used.' The dress of choice for Ned Ingham's guests is always a white or cream number with a long skirt, and of course a bit of flair added with a tiara and other jewels. This means more white and beading. 'But don't forget the big white tiaras.' For the bride-to-be, the style of dress Ned Ingham suggests this year for her is a'smooth, classic silhouette with a slightly open skirt and a low back and a high neckline. Many parents may even fail to recognise and respond to their child's need until frustration explodes into difficult or uncooperative behaviour. A NEW LIFE The Farmer Matt Froggatt used to be an insurance agent in the City of London but now runs a sheep farm. 'After 14 years in business I found that the City had gone from a place which was exciting to work in to a grind - no one was having fun any more. I didn't want that to happen to my farm,' he explains. 'But now people come to the farm for a rural lifestyle. They want something to be proud of, to look forward to. I want people to have an experience which they will remember for years to come.' He's also got a keen eye for design and the sheep and lambs will soon be seen in his new shop: 'The sheep will be in the front, the shop in the side. It's a big old building but we've gone away from the old way of doing things. With the sheep we've gone in and made it simple. We're using modern designs and things like that. 'There will be a good mix of domestic and commercial.' Froggatt's farm is a working example of what can happen when a farmer takes a job outside his trade - a lifestyle that might only last for a few months, but one which ends up long lasting. We went on a sheep trip with him and his son and his wife, who runs the kitchen. But before we went up on the farm we stopped off to pick up the farmer at a place he'd suggested - a coffee shop called Cafe Rouge. I'd heard about it, so thought we'd give it a go, the farmer told me. So I drove down there with the boy and we met Matt, his wife Jenny and their two sons Luke and Alex, aged 10 and seven. We changed lives for a day! Have you ever dreamed about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Perhaps you think it would be more fun to do something quite different for a change? We fixed it for four people - read how it went.
We swapped lives with five people. This way everyone got to live a different kind of day. We changed the person's life and also their own. We made a day out of their worst nightmare. They can now say: "I have never been homeless." We even had an opportunity to give them a new identity as well. It was a unique chance for them to show their personality and their talents.
We swapped lives with a family. They have always been worried about money and, as a result, they have always been afraid. In one day, the family can say: "We have always been poor but we are now rich." We got to know them better and we were able to offer our support. We were able to give them our money and we were able to change their life for the better.
Now it's time to get back to normal. But we didn't really leave the world behind. We left it with the memories. The money and a new identity have gone but we left with our hearts.
It was a fantastic and fun experience for all of us. But the most important thing was that we got to know the family better and understand them more. We were able to help them change for the better and to make them feel happier and more successful.
All in all, it was an unforgettable and memorable day. We learned a lot from each other and we gained new friends for life. It is important to understand your families' emotions. They all

Dorothy who? The only British woman scientist to win the Nobel prize should be a household name in her own country says Georgina Ferry but she is little known For the past four years I have been subjecting friends and acquaintances to the Dorothy Hodgkin test. It's very simple: when asked what I am working on I tell them I am writing the first biography of Dorothy Hodgkin. If they are asked what Dorothy is they say'she is the female scientist who won the Nobel prize for medicine for discovering the gene for Hodgkin's disease'. If they insist that I give them the full name they insist that I spell it 'Dorothy Hodgkin'. 'Dorothy Hodgkin?' they say. 'I can't help it, the name sounds too foreign. I prefer to think of her as Mrs. Hodgkin.' The result is a stream of blank expressions and, occasionally, tears. No matter how many times I repeat the name I know I will be met with blank stares and the same unhelpful shrug as before. If it has already come up in conversation I am usually met with silence and a puzzled expression. If they say that my pronunciation is off, I point out that there are only two 'k's' in 'Dorothy' and explain that I speak with a London accent. Even if they don't know why I pronounce it 'Dorothy', they are invariably puzzled to learn that this is what I am talking about. A few days later, when we were talking about a case of Hodgkin's disease which was giving so much trouble that a new treatment was needed, they began to tell me what happened to Dorothy. 'She invented a vaccine.' I explained this to them but they had no idea what I was on about. What about the name 'Dorothy Hodgkin' is confusing them?You've given them

Under Sarah's Spell Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist whose paintings are designed to deceive the eye by creating the illusion of reality. Here she is interviewed by Joanna Watt There cannot he many artists who l10 not sign their work unless they are asked to. Sarah Janson a trompe-l'oeil artist is one. Janson started tromping in the 80's using her art as a means of escape. To give her a distraction, she painted a series of strange images to take away the mind set and to be enthralled for a short time. She has used all kinds of different materials from paper to oil to rubber to paint the images. Many of her paintings are now available at her website http://www.sarahjansons.com/ Sarah does have a signature which is printed in the corner to ensure the piece is real. This is the only way she knows that the piece is for sale. Sarah is very selective with what paintings she sells. Her paintings sell very well but she only makes one or two of a series. Her paintings are limited in the sense that she only makes a very small number of each. Janson's work has been shown at the following shows: New York, London, Toronto, and Washington D.C. Sarah's work is featured on the trompe-l'oeil show at The Museum of Fine Arts Houston. The show opened in May 2012. The show was put on by Robert B. Parker and David Wrobel. The show will be on display through 2013. For more information click the link below. The Museum of Fine Arts Houston Trompe-l'oeil Show. New In Paperback A. The career of citizen Tristan Smith set in the fictional republic of Efica is an extraordinary parable of human power history and humour. In a feat of considerable literary skill the author has created a world with its own history traditions and customs. The story is told by the wise, noble and intelligent Tristan Smith. His love of literature and his devotion to learning and reason lead him to a lifetime of service to his kingdom and the people. However, just as he is about to get on with his work, a plague has hit his city and kills half the population. The king blames the death on a local sorcerer known as The Demon of Efica who is at once the most beloved and reviled man in the whole country. Tristan vows to end the demon's reign. When the demon is killed, Tristan feels a power greater than his own and he vows to become the new king. The story proceeds and many people in the kingdom fall ill. Tristan begins to suspect the deaths are the work of the demon. A cure for the plague is found, but the king refuses to allow it to be administered to those who can't be trusted. When more deaths occur, Tristan decides that he must find out if the cause of the plague is witchcraft or disease. The result of his investigation finds the king guilty of witchcraft. Tristan decides to destroy the witch's house. However, as he arrives he realises that the house is not a witch's house at all but the home of a very clever witch with a gift of prophecy. A trumpet isn’t just for Christmas… It is strange how many musicians even leading ones come from homes without music. Out of the blue Hakan Hardenberger the only son of totally unmusical parents in a country district of southern Sweden has at the age of 30 established himself as unique among the world’s trumpet-players today. He first appeared on the music scene with his first quartet during the first years of his life. Now, at the age of 38, with five albums and a wide variety of recordings and concerts under his belt and a regular contract with a label in Stockholm, he continues his adventure in this musical journey that started way back when he was just nine years old. It is indeed amazing to see such a beautiful instrument as the trumpet being used in such a versatile way. It is amazing how far he has come!
The very first quartet he ever joined was a small group of children and teenagers that played in the same school in Upplands Listan. During his years of training and preparation he was a soloist in many school and college bands and the young musician started his musical journey back in the second year of high-school. It was in this second year when he first played at the music school in Uppsala with the Uppsala National Symphony Orchestra. After a few years at university he started the Royal Stockholm Conservatoire in which he has been living for almost 15 years. In 2004 he won an international competition in the trumpet and in 2005 the prize for a classical ensemble with the same school as him, where he was a soloist. The following year he also won the best trumpet soloist in the competition in Stockholm. He continued this tradition and won the prizes for best trumpet soloist in 2009 and in 2012 and 2013. HENLOW GRANGE I welcomed the opportunity to go to Henlow Grange for six days as I was tired and needed to relax. I love taking my children to country pubs and the Grange was a treat. I like the setting of the pub, the ambience is pleasant and the food was very good. The pub is open from 10am to 4pm. I had the fish and chips with a pint of dark beer and a slice of lemon drizzle cake. The owner’s daughter did a lovely little job in the pub and I was very happy with the service that I received. I would definitely come back. THE BANDIT HALL I enjoyed The Bandit Hall thoroughly. I really felt at home here. The owner welcomed me in and I enjoyed my time there with a warm welcome. He had said exactly the name Emma wanted him to say. Now she could suggest that it was difficult to explain matters by letter and she offered to go over to Rouen and speak to him directly. Charles would not hear of troubling her. She insisted. It was a battle of kindness. 

The next day, the day they had agreed to meet, Emma wrote to explain her decision to go to Rouen. She had been quite ill all night. Her stomach was upset. As a doctor, Dr. Gaudron believed it prudent to see the surgeon. Emma was grateful for the time together, but she was also concerned for Charles’s condition, and that of their son. Charles explained the situation briefly, while Emma tried to compose herself and compose her letter. 

I will go to Rouen tomorrow. It is not far from where we met this evening. Perhaps I will see you there. I am very sorry that I will not be able to say good-bye in person, but it is just impossible. I can write for hours, but I will not be able to stop saying how much I love you until I do. I do not know how to explain this.
You must have no fear. I am with God, and I have promised him to return.

With love,

Your sweetheart,

Emma, 16, February, 1840 

On Friday, she wrote, she had been able to compose a more personal letter. She was tired, but her courage was growing. Her heart was breaking, but it was stronger.

Career Power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work. A. What makes a good leader? A leader is one who inspires an agent of change a developer who shows the way forward. Leadership is not about breeding or height - taller being better as the early theorists believed. They were wrong as the leaders of the world today prove - their short stature did not hinder them as they led from the front. Leadership is about vision, passion and commitment - and the right mindset. Your ability to deliver value through vision and passion will make you stand out as a leader. You need vision and passion to drive your organisation. Your passion for the organisation drives you towards development and innovation which helps the organisation achieve more. And as you become more passionate about the organisation, you become more innovative and determined to lead it. You then become an agent of change. To become an agent of change you need not only the motivation but you also need the ability to lead. You need the motivation to lead your team, and you also need the ability to lead. Motivation is the ability to turn challenges into opportunities for your team. There are three main sources of motivation: personal goals, company goals and group goals. In many organisations, all or a portion of their goals are personal, group or company goals. A motivated person will strive for success and happiness in his personal life and career. There are three ways to motivate yourself: setting goals, planning goals and achieving goals. 1. Setting goals can be easier said than done. The reason for this is that goals often require a lot of planning and analysis which requires a lot of effort. Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success Daniel Goleman examines the 'people skills' that are essential for a place at the top of your profession A The rules for work are changing We are being judged by a new yardstick - not just by how clever we are or by our training and expertise but also by how well we handle ourselves and each other. Emotional intelligence (EI) is a term that has been thrown around a lot in business, but what is EI? It is a mental ability measured by those who practice it - you. It is being able to handle uncertainty and ambiguity effectively and to maintain positive emotional states while remaining focused on the task at hand. A person's emotional state has an impact on their performance, particularly on their motivation to do work, as described in Daniel Goleman's new book. It is a simple premise but one that is difficult to convey to the non-business person. The book begins with a list of definitions, but the best way to read this book is to think of it as a roadmap for managing emotions at work. It is divided into five chapters. The first two are based on Goleman's own experience at the New York Times, including an interview with Jim Collins on Emotional Intelligence. Chapter three focuses on "How to Manage Emotions at Work," and the fourth chapter looks at "The Way We Think About Work and What That Means for Management." The final chapter considers the "people skills" that make a person successful at work. For me, the key part of the book is the last two chapters. They offer strategies for working with your coworkers, leaders and clients and also present a series of exercises for developing your own emotional intelligence. The first of these is called "The Four Practices of Emotional Intelligence," and you will find a number of exercises in the first

Careers Six people talk about their typical working day A. Credit Card Executive I get up at 6 am to arrive at the office around 7.30 am. I manage all the customer development programmes for our regular credit card users. My responsibilities include the launch and management of the Membership Rewards scheme in the major European markets. I deal with each new member on the pitch and we manage the entire credit product. I also handle all the credit card payments and keep track of all the changes in the business, including the customer's requirements. I am involved in the sales and marketing strategy of our company. I work at least 10 hours a day. My company also has a part time project manager to assist me. He is based in the US. The project manager helps me in keeping in touch with all the relevant authorities and our customers. At the end of each day I meet my wife and make the payments for the household. After my duties I relax by surfing the internet, playing the guitar or spending some time with my family and friends. I can also play tennis and basketball in the evening with my friend and family. During the weekends I travel to the beach and relax for a couple of hours. On Wednesdays I spend the day working on my personal projects. I am very active in my personal life. At the moment I live in London and I enjoy my city and the British culture. We spend time shopping, restaurants and travelling. 

Education I studied Economics at the University of Reading. I am also a life member of the British Chamber of Commerce.

Sound the Alarm Stuart Harris reports Many of us listen to the radio when we get up in the morning and most of us also require some external means to persuade us to get out of bed. Thus we have the clock radio. But how do you pick a good one? You don't. So the industry says. A new study has just confirmed their fears by suggesting that our preferred modes of communication are no more effective at raising awareness and behaviour change than are the more familiar methods. The researchers say it is better to choose a non-traditional method. One that will engage the listener and make them feel that they are part of the programme. Such an approach would be best suited to providing the right information at the right time on the radio rather than being a substitute for an alert message on television. The findings were published in the British Journal of Public Health. The researchers used a simple test to measure our preference for certain types of content. They used a telephone survey of 545 people in which they asked respondents to press a button to answer. A computer then tracked how quickly they pressed the button. The more they pressed it the faster they responded. The results were consistent across the age group and the type of questions asked. We liked listening to announcements at 4am when we were reading a story. But we were also willing to listen to programmes that were designed to encourage us to make a change. The results are interesting for all sorts of purposes. First, the findings are consistent with the idea that "promising messages" are not better than those that are "banned". That is, a "good" message could be banned by the media and if that is so then the media should produce alternative messages that are more appealing. That's because the "bad" messages

With the trees I planted my stake in New Zealand JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER Jonallum Porritt is the author of Seeing Green - The Politics ofEcology'. I HAD a most peculiar period of my life when I didn’t have any summers. I spent one year on a farm in rural New Zealand where there was no snow on the trees, and I took an apprenticeship on a farm in Wales where we had a lot of snow in the trees, and then I returned to New Zealand. In between I had nothing to do. It was wonderful to sit in the living room and read, write letters and go to church and not do anything. It took about four years to finish my degree. I had a lot of fun then, doing nothing. My favourite book at the moment is A Tree For My Dad by Jonathan Yardley. It is a book about the trees and how they have inspired nature in our lives. It gives you the chance to look at the trees and see how much they mean to us and how much we love them. It has really inspired me to start planting trees here in London again. We need to keep creating more forests in London so they continue to be part of our landscape. It is so important. You can think about it all the time and people don’t realise how many trees are gone in London. You just don’t realise. One tree can produce two tonnes of carbon dioxide. When you can think about that it really makes you feel the effect that we have on the trees. I always used to think how lucky we are to have a small amount of space to work with. We are so lucky. Hide and Seek Yvonne Coppard Emma and her friends are pursuing a holiday game — surveillance of a suspicious bookshop — when she realises that one of its rare customers is her Uncle Jim. He callously draws her into a web of deceit and crime manipulating her affection for him and attempting to alienate her from her friends whose characters are persuasively drawn by Coppard. A clever blend of thriller, mystery, social drama and black comedy with a lightening of tone which sets a tone for the rest of the film. The film is funny and amusing and the soundtrack with its songs (written by Coppard) is charming and musical. The film ends with a lovely song sung by the film's stars that expresses how much the film makes us feel like we know its characters. - IMDb

P. D. James Barbara Michaels meets the acclaimed crime writer whose innocent exterior hides a complex and brilliant imagination. Best-selling crime writer P.D. James - the initials stand for Phyllis Dorothy - exudes an air of quiet authority. It is easy to envisage her had she not become a creator of detective stories with more twists and turns than a spiral staircase as a headmistress of a girls' school. One of these, a trilogy, has been nominated for the Booker Prize, in recognition of the talent of the author. She lives in Berkshire with her husband, a solicitor who works out of London. Michaels begins her conversation with a memory: "The year before I was married, I was living in rural Surrey. I lived with my aunt and uncle, who had given me a cottage. I was in love with the local farmer's son. There was a great deal to talk about, and, like all teenagers, we talked about everything under the sun." I confess, like any teenager myself, I could talk, very loudly, about absolutely anything under the sun. What was her name, again? She paused, and I realised, because of the long silence, she was thinking about something. "We discussed everything," she said, "even a certain murder." Great sports Women on a winning streak To excel in any sport is hard enough even far men but women have to be twice as tough. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life so sacrifices must be made. But against all the odds they are beating prejudice and breaking records.
What makes these women successful? We know one main factor is that they never stop trying. A female athlete needs to be dedicated, work hard and never give up.
5. Practice makes perfect.: It's not just in sports that women are able to succeed. The fact that they practice makes it easier for them. 6. Keep your head high.: When things don't go as well as you wanted, you have to think to yourself that it was only a game. Remember that you were never beaten. When you start feeling down, just look at the next practice and find a way to win.

I saw a lot of things he said. "And I know a lot more. This visit is about money. Mr. Phelan promised that he would take care of me in his will. There were many promises all broken." "Was he crazy?" "He was or he wasn't. Doesn't matter to me. I didn't care about dying anyway. I wanted to live again." He wanted the money." "Was it to escape the justice of the court?" "I didn't want the legal trouble with my name attached to the deal. I didn't want to appear in front of the people. So I made a quick deal. Mr. Phelan promised to send me to an island and let me hide there. And I got my wish. I hid in an island somewhere on the Atlantic Ocean. But it wasn't the best hiding place. There were so many people looking for me. They got impatient and started killing each other. I was hiding on a boat that was drifting. They killed the people on it. It was like a war between the sea and the land. It was terrifying." "There was a whole army waiting for you, Mr. Phelan." "I waited and waited. And finally, a ship came. They took me to the new world. The new world was much better, much warmer, much more welcoming to me. I lived there happily for fifty years. And I have one regret. I didn't have a family." "You were a wealthy man. You could have helped someone like me." "I tried but I couldn't make them understand. They were so stubborn." "I see. But I did help you one other time." BRINGING UP BADGERS ‘What now?’ was my immediate thought as one of my helpers canned a cardboard box towards me. Since my husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an ‘open farm’ six years ago we’ve established a reputation for looking after orphaned animals. In the last 18 months alone we’ve found homes for a cat, bunny and turtle all after being rescued from the local abattoir. Now we’re on the lookout for a baby donkey and we could use your help.
I was about to make another run to the canteen to get some water when I remembered the box I’d brought back home from the supermarket the day before. Derek spotted it out of sight in a corner and said he’d get it for me. Now I knew why I hadn’t heard any noises.
He had indeed. As soon as he saw the box he had one of those bemused shrugs. "I thought you might have been up to something," he said.
As soon as Derek had the donkey in his arms it had been easy to fall in love with him. He was just as plump as my favourite doll and as easy to handle as a cuddly toy.
I sat on his back and held his tiny front legs in front of me. It felt like a dream. The donkey looked back at me and I was lost for words.
The old farmhouse where we live is a three hour drive from the nearest market town, and we knew from experience that we’d never be able to take care of this one alone. Our neighbours know we run the donkey clinic and would be delighted to help. The farmer next door has a family of eight small children

DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS? We asked five leading British publishers about the effect of the reviews of a book on its commercial success. Here is what they said. Publisher A Reviews are absolutely key for publishers - the first part of the newspaper we turn to. The reviews in the newspapers do not tell us whether a book is worthwhile or not - what the reviews say about whether the book will be a good success is what does the books sales. The second part of the newspaper is where the advertising is. Where do the sales come from? There are many reasons behind why a book is successful. It may have been a bestseller, but may not have been a big seller. It may have been popular, but may not have been a bestseller. It may have received a very good review, but not many, a bad one or even a mixed review. And it may have been a very popular book, but not popular enough to make money. However the reason that a book becomes a big success or a success is that the reviews, which have always had an effect, in some cases significantly affect the sales. Some publishers will take this into account when they choose the titles of the books that they publish. However, in other cases, they will ignore what the reviews say. This is because they will say "That sounds like a very good idea. I will publish it". The fact is, however, that, in either case, the book sales will be very high, but, it will not matter which version is chosen as long as the reviews are positive. And, if reviews are not positive, it won't matter which version is chosen. But, it is not just publishers. Books are bought by readers, people who have already decided that

Advertisement The tobacco industry has made more than $70 billion by convincing parents and school teachers that they are not involved in their children's addiction to cigarettes. And their advertisements have convinced young adults that their smoking is not unhealthy. According to a Harvard Medical School report on teen smoking in the United States, the television programs and newspapers in which tobacco firms have sponsored their product are the most influential factors in teenagers' ability to smoke. The average American teenager can only choose from about a dozen major cigarette companies, each advertising various products and making a range of claims concerning their safety, including claims that smoking reduces health risks. Advertisement The advertising campaign in the United States is estimated to have been the strongest in the world, in terms of dollar value. The top 20 television networks and 25 newspapers devoted almost as many minutes to advertising tobacco companies as to all the other news about the world, such as the death toll from famine, war, terrorism, and other ills of the world. The journey from our town to the capital was a journey of about five hours. When I arrived at Mr Jaggers's office the clerk told me that he was in court and that he had left word I should wait in his room. He led me to a dark room. It was a large one. The clerk told me that Mr Jaggers was not in, so we must wait. After an hour I heard him approaching. It was dark and cold, so I put on my coat and went out. At the gate I saw him coming back in a taxi and I followed him. He stopped at a crossroad and went to a barbers' shop. There he was at 5 in the morning. The barber cut off his hair in three rows. Then I saw Mr Jaggers leaving the shop. I ran and found a taxi waiting for me at the gate. The taxi was empty except for the man who drove it. I got in the taxi and I saw him looking at me with a smile. The taxi drove away. When we got to his house, we saw his wife sitting on the sofa and his dog playing on the carpet. I took my things to his bedroom and then went to bed. I was woken up by a strange noise. There were dogs barking, and at that moment Mr Jaggers knocked on the door. "Come in! My secretary is in the bedroom!" I heard a voice say. I opened the door and there was Mr Jaggers dressed in a suit. I followed him into the hall, where I saw a man carrying his hat. The long-distance runner Richard Nerurkar one of Britain's top 10000-metre runners visits the Kenyans’ high-altitude training camp. Ten miles south of the equator a sony mountain track leads off the quiet metalled road from Nairobi. The track marks the start of the trek up Kenya's highest peak the glacier-capped Mount Kenya. The following day, an altitude of around 2,846m above sea level, awaits. The trek continues to Naivasha, home of the national stadium, where the runners train together as a single team. Richard finds out how the Kenyan team is determined to improve their results.
Producer: David Ranson (DavidRanson.co.uk) 
Co-Producer: Nicky Jackson (NickyJackson.co.uk) 
Editor: Paul Houghton (paulhoughton.co.uk) 

Kenya is at the heart of the Great Lakes Region, making the country a natural filming location. The area offers the perfect backdrop for outdoor adventures as well as the opportunity to enjoy a culture and language that can be found nowhere else. 

"Highlights of your trip and why you chose them?"The high altitude training camp in Naivasha is a great way for an athlete to further improve their speed and stamina. The Kenyan team trains together as a single team. It helps build the rapport between everyone. During their training session they are not distracted by spectators. They just concentrate on themselves. This is a great opportunity to get to know the country. As well as the great running weather the country offers plenty of outdoor activities. There are fantastic views over the countryside and you can find a range of wildlife in the surrounding areas. You can do all this in a matter of days. The location is ideal for filming

This week. the Summer Boat Show in London is resplendent with fine yachts bristling with new technology. Nearly all are descendants of the hull-shape revolution that took place 25 years ago. Tom Cunliffe was in the dock this year. This elegant motor boat, called The Westerman, is an ideal example. It combines a clean, elegant hull shape, with a powerful, fuel-efficient motor. Tom Cunliffe's design won best motor yacht in the 2006 World Boat Show and this year. The boat's owners have built a very successful marina at the edge of the Dartmoor national park. In a few months, the Westerman, a hybrid motor/sail boat, will arrive on the Devon coast. In the meantime, it is being fitted at a small boat yard in Oxford. But, in many respects, the Westerman is a normal motor yacht, a'super yacht' if you like. It is 36 feet long with a beam of 9 feet 6 inches. It can carry 24 guests, or 16 crew in the very spacious accommodation. A good amount of space is taken up by a huge saloon, that is the largest saloon on a motor yacht that I have ever seen. There is a dining area off the saloon. And there are six further bedrooms. But, of more interest to the readers of this magazine, there is a huge open-air salon with a huge glass panelled room off it. The saloon's design has the advantage of using a lot of glass. The sun can pour in during the day. And it doesn't have to worry about wind-swept decks. It is easy

Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small mammal characterised by the sharp spines which cover its body. The hedgehogs are found in many different parts of the world none is native to either America or Australia. All species of hedgehog share the ability to roll into a tight ball when attacked so that their spines point outwards. The hedgehogs can be found in their natural habitat around the world. All hedgehogs are carnivores but their diet varies depending on the environment in which they live. Hedgeshogs are members of the rodent order Chiropodia. They are very similar in appearance to rats. They share the ability to roll into a tight ball, making them defenceless against predators. Hedgeshogs are generally harmless to people unless attacked by large animals like otters, which kill hedgehogs often. A hedgehog will typically live for between 4 - 8 years, depending on the area they live in. When they are large they can live for 15 - 20 years. There is no clear cut definition of what constitutes a hedgehog. A male hedgehog may look similar to a female and a female may look similar to a male. However, there is only one male and only one female from each population. The hedgehog only needs to live in the wild to be able to reproduce so they are usually raised by an animal of their own species. All hedgehogs are solitary animals, but when they do interact they usually remain on their own. When they become old enough they start to live with groups of other hedgehogs. There are four major types of hedgehog. The first type has a flat body, but their spine are pointed. The second type has spines at the front and back of its body, with a flattened head. The third type have long spines attached

Blacksmiths THROUGHOUT the ages iron has exerted a powerful pull on the human imagination and the men who work it have often been regarded as much more than skilled craftsmen. Before the Industrial Revolution blacksmiths enjoyed the same status as doctors and astrologers because they were the sole providers of weapons armour and farming tools. They were also thought to possess mystical power.

The work of a blacksmith is divided into three phases. The first phase is the forging of metal into weapons and armour. The second involves the repair of iron or metal that has already been forged or is damaged. The final phase is the smelting of metals to produce steel.

In medieval times blacksmiths also repaired farm equipment such as ploughs. Medieval blacksmiths also found work as judges and as police officers during times of plague. The medieval blacksmith was also thought to have had the ability to create ghosts.

When the Industrial Revolution broke out a blacksmith was the only one who could provide these essential products. With the coming of the 20th Century a whole new industry was born but the blacksmith tradition still lives on and has created a wide range of products in shops around the world.

A blacksmith uses two sticks and a hammer to smash apart steel bars in a forge. Each bar is made out of different metals such as iron and copper and some are harder than others. The hardest ones are used for weapons and armour. The best swords are made out of iron and if they are not, steel is a good substitute. An iron sword will be more expensive than a steel sword so it takes longer to make. Iron is hard to forge and the heat can cause it to warp. Steel also requires less heat but it requires a better hammer. There are also many other factors that go

In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet Dr Toby Clark a researcher at the British Geological Survey aims to retrace Sir Edmund Halley's quest to chart compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports. Astronomer Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is best known for the comet that bears his name. He also drew up his famous Chart of Celestial Latitudes, whose data was used as the basis for the British government's navigational system. Dr Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, is setting off on a quest to retrace Halley's quest to chart compass variations. He's been researching the comet since 2009 and is currently exploring the southern sky. He's been exploring the southern sky and discovering a new constellation, Sirius. He's also noticed that Halley's comet is much dimmer today than in the early 19th century. He says it has a lot to do with the solar system's recent evolution. Advertisement
Sir Edmund Halley was born in 1656. He was an astronomer, physician, and mathematician. His comet is known as Halley's and it is visible today.
He was a member of the Royal Society. He co-discovered a comet with William Shakespeare, Comet Ptolemy.
Sir Edmund was the chief navigator of the King's Ships.
Sir Edmund was responsible for charting the northern and southern hemispheres of the earth.
Sir Edmund was the father of Edward, 2nd Baronet (1691-1751) and Lady Eleanor (née Halley).
He also fathered a daughter who was named in his honor. This daughter was an accomplished lady and became a lady in waiting.
He died on 20 December 1742. He was buried at his beloved cottage, known as the Royal

For the most adventurous, a helicopter ride is arranged at a very competitive price, including dinner.

I would recommend to anyone that is interested in staying at a hotel in Rajasthan.
Thank you Sajjan Singh

Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares with his readers the mystical experience of conquering the highest peak on each continent: the Seven Summits. My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I will take them in the order of my climbing them. A. Mt. Everest: I arrived at the North Pole and made my way around South America. In Peru I made my way to the Inca Trail for my first summit. I took my next trip to the Himalayas with a company called Mountaineering Adventures. We climbed many of the highest peaks in the Himalayas. One of my favorite destinations we visited was the Nanda Devi Range. The summit of Nanda Devi was our highest point. A. Mt. Kanchenjunga: This mountain was my first summit. In Tibet it was the first mountain I ever tried to climb. I climbed it as part of my Mount Everest Project. As you can see from the image, it was the most difficult climb. We had to climb to the highest point we could find, then descend to the North Side of the mountain to the South Side. This was very tiring work. There were many times I would just collapse and sleep for an hour on the way down. However, I made it. I continued to climb with Mountaineering Adventures, which brought me to A. Mt. Annapurna. Here is a great photo I took of the mountaineers arriving at this mountain. I was able to spend time with the mountaineers, climb the mountain and have fun! A. Mt. Kullu: This mountain was our highest at 8,079 feet. Our summit was beautiful. Photographing People People are the most interesting of all subjects. A photograph with someone in it is almost always more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. People are also the most difficult subjects to photograph well. Apart from the technical and artistic considerations the photographer has to be conscious of actions gestures and expressions. The aim of photography is to document our world. So it becomes the aim of a photographer to be aware and pay attention to the details and movements of subjects. In other words, to photograph people so as to capture an image worthy of publication.
  
 We have already been discussing the basics. What do we usually use to photograph people? A camera with a lens. In the past the most popular camera was the medium format SLR (Single Length Roll-Cam). However, due to technological advances and changes in film and lens manufacturing the modern SLR is no longer the most popular camera for photographers. Instead of the SLR we are witnessing the birth of digital cameras. They have more advantages than their previous digital counterparts but it’s the price that is probably the most important consideration for most photographers.
  
 Some people still use the SLR cameras, not because they want to but because of the convenience they offer. They are the ideal camera for serious photographers, those who do not want to leave their studio for a long time.
  
 Another important consideration for photographers is the quality of the photographs. If the subject is not a good fit for the camera then it will produce a blurry result. Also, even a blurry picture can still be interesting. But again, the key is whether the subject fits the camera or not.

The Hotel Inspector Sue Brown judges hotels for a living. Christopher Middleton watched her in action. One minute into the annual inspection and things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel. Not that they know it yet. The receptionist reciting room rates over the phone to a potential guest is still blissfully unaware of the identity of the real guest she is doggedly ignoring. The hotel has had an unhappy past in the past, and it is now in serious need of a new lease of life, especially with the recent success of The Great Tourist Trade. But the new ownership, the brothers Gogarty, plan to make their business fortunes by ripping apart the very building their family has been in since its first days, a building that stands at the center of all the hotel’s activity. An old building with a new face. All too soon, the hotel is being torn down, and the brothers, with only a skeleton crew to carry out the demolition, attempt to have all of the windows removed and then move in. In a bid to save the building and restore it to the glory it once held, the brothers Gogarty create a fake guest room that is exactly the same as the rooms they would be ripping out. Hotel Inspector Sue Brown finds out exactly how far the Gogarty brothers will go to get their hotel back into the black, and how much they are willing to risk to do it. It all comes down to one decision: Is it right to rip out the people who have spent their life here, or is it right to restore the old hotel? Can they make a better home for their old hotel than the Gogarty brothers ever could? Or will they all get to go back home?

Reviews of The Hotel Inspector Sue Brown:

The film is entertaining as a story, but not captivating. There

The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst The study of handwriting to reveal a person’s character is gaining support If you applied for a job in some countries you would almost certainly be asked for a sample of your handwriting. And it would be the handwriting as much as anything else that would determine your suitability for the job. That’s because most people think of handwriting as a way of revealing a person’s values. Now it seems that some researchers are suggesting that there is another kind of quality they could be measuring in handwriting: the writer’s character. This could suggest that a person’s behaviour can be judged by the way they write. The research, carried out by Martin Groskirch of the University of Basel, Switzerland, and his colleagues, suggests that handwriting contains clues about personality that can be measured. It turns out that if you compare people who are of the same personality but with different handwriting styles you can get a measure of the personality of one based on the other. Those who were of the same personality and the same style had identical handwriting, but those who were of different personalities and different styles had different handwriting. And those who had the same handwriting and were of the same personality were identical to those who had different handwriting and were of a different personality. Some of the clues they uncovered are pretty obvious. People who have a dominant dominant writing style are usually more organised than those who don’t. But you can still look deeper into how people write and determine a person’s personality. For example, people who write in a blocky cursive script have an extra personality that is not always obvious. Some have a tendency to be aggressive and some to be more considerate, for example. And if someone has a particular way of writing which makes it

Volunteer tourism Four academic writers discuss the topic of international voluntary work. A. It is hard to argue that the actual contribution to development amounts to a great deal directly.
In the same way, some voluntary workers can do more harm than good, by overworking themselves, overshooting their intended target in terms of time, and overachieving in terms of results.
The question is: should voluntary workers be paid?
Voluntary tourism is important. So what? What we do is important. So are the decisions we make. What matters most is how we work and our decision-making processes. These should be guided by the needs of the project and the community that we are working with.
These days, we have many examples of the positive impact of volunteer work. We should not forget that volunteers are, by nature, altruistic. There are many good works of the volunteers in this field. But there are also also examples of waste. In addition to the waste caused by the volunteers, we also have the risks related to diseases and terrorism.
We should also not forget that in international tourism, an increasing number of tourists comes to India from the Middle East and North Africa. The increase is mainly due to increased political tension and conflict, such as the war in Syria and the ongoing tensions in Yemen. These are two major factors that make it hard for the tourists to visit a country that is not free from conflict.
This also affects the businesses that are associated with tourism, such as hotels and restaurants. This is not only because of the tourism itself, but also because, as the tourists are going to visit certain places of interest that they

A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology The Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few surviving collections of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture in the world comprising over six hundred works. The first thing to remember about the collection is that nothing here is genuine. All the sculptures are accurate replicas cast from the originals mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Every cast is a “perfect match” to any other that is known to exist. The most obvious way to tell the difference between sculptures is with the use of a microscope. In a typical museum exhibition the work is arranged chronologically so that what was the “last used” is the farthest from the front. It is always easier to identify “the wrong one” when works are spread like that, but this is not always a practical way of looking at an exhibition. You might well say that most museums are like that (that this is how most exhibitions are), but in the case of the University Museum of Classical Archaeology the work is arranged in such a way that “the most recent one” is very close to the back. Also, the “most recent” is often an older cast than any of the others. The display can also be quite confusing, since there are so many different models and sizes of sculptures and models and models that are hard to compare to one another, and so much of the cast selection is made on the basis of what is “the most recent” (and least expensive). There are some exceptions to all of this, and there are other museums that display the whole range of Greek and Roman sculpture in a more realistic way, but for the general viewer this is the best way to understand the exhibition. When the exhibition opens, all the casts are being exhibited together, but with a careful balance on the

Are you too nice for your own good? When I had my first job as a waitress in a restaurant I soon learnt that the best way to get myself out of trouble was to smile sweetly at every possible opportunity. 'I'm so sorry' I beamed when I dropped the plate on the floor and it smashed into smithereens. It is a habit I have kept ever since. I make a point of smiling at all customers every day, whether they are happy or not. It is often my duty to smile at strangers at the airport and on trains. There is nothing more annoying than being seated next to someone who looks annoyed to be there. So I smile, wave back and say a quick 'hello' every time. It may not seem polite or considerate of me to force my way into people's lives. But sometimes I do have a conscience. For instance I was sitting in a cinema last night and the person next to me was not smiling. I thought he looked bored. I smiled at him and said 'Hello'. I felt that I owed it to him to smile too. You might think I'm an insincere grin-wearer. But I try not to let my smiling be superficial. I look everyone in the eye when I am smiling. And I am not afraid to say 'hello' if someone else's eyes are downcast. I do not see any reason to lie, not when I smile all day. So I do not let myself believe that my smiles do not mean anything. Maybe they don't. And maybe my kindness and good cheer really are just part of my personality. And if it is so, then I want to spread it. That is my dream. But I must have some good sense about it, too. So I smile even when I am about to have a

Science flying in the face of gravity Journalist Tom Mumford joins students using weightlessness to test their theories. It looked like just another aircraft from the outside. The pilot told his young passengers that it was built in 1964 a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker based on the Boeing 707 passenger craft. The aircrew gave a tour of the craft inside the cabin. There were no windows, except for the few in the cockpit, which faced a black screen behind a safety wall. But all around the cabin there was weightlessness. The four passengers, aged 11 to 20, looked around and then ran outside to stand on the tarmac and look up at the planes. Some went into the cockpit and did some pilot training. “That’s OK. We’re in space,” a 12-year-old boy joked. There were two flight deck pilots, a flight engineer and a navigator. “It’s my first time!” said one. The KC-135 could carry up to 100,000 litres of fuel. During the flight the crew would monitor fuel levels and also fly to maintain a constant altitude. There was no chance of falling into the abyss below. The Boeing has an unusually shaped fuselage with long wings, which give it a very spacious interior. The passengers sat up front, each with their own reclining seats. Most also had a bunk bed in the cabin and a big screen to which they could watch TV. The children were fascinated by a large fan that was attached to one of the windows. The cabin was divided into two parts by thick white curtains. “There are more things flying than us!” joked one of the older students. The kids climbed aboard the KC-135 to watch it take off

The day I drew Picasso Richard Cork recalls how as an 78-year-old student he came face-to-face with one of the most revered artists of the century. Even seen at a distance eating his lunch at an open-air restaurant in Cannes harbour Picasso was instantly recognisable. I was an I8-year-old student filling in time before university by travelling round Europe and Morocco in a battered and unreliable van. We set off for the Riviera from the centre of Bordeaux on a warm late summer evening. We had no real plan and wandered aimlessly through the vineyards in search of food to keep us warm. Picasso and a companion, who had been drinking, saw us from a distance and went into the restaurant for a cigarette. I don’t know if Picasso ever saw the boy drawing on the walls of the restaurant but for the rest of the year I was convinced he saw me too. He made a point of thanking me for sharing our trip. In the end I came to Paris to study architecture but when I met the artist for the first time I knew I’d made the wrong choice of career. In an interview with The Times in 1961 he recalled a brief encounter with a seven-year-old boy who had been given his lunch by Picasso. “I was eating my lunch at an open-air restaurant in Cannes harbour, and I noticed a little boy there and decided to draw him to amuse myself,” he said. “At first he did not come near me. I tried to attract his attention by talking to him about art and history, and he looked at me for a long time, and then finally, he took off his glove and gave me the sketch.” The boy had never forgotten that moment and, to this day, he still brings the sketch to school every year when it’s due. Hit and miss of mass marketing AS ALMOST everyone knows advertising is in the doldrums. It isn't just the recession. Advertising started to plummet early in 1989 well before the recession really began to bite. Advertising's problems are more fundamental and the decline is worldwide. The unhappy truth is that advertising has failed to keep up with the pace of economic change.

In the past advertising was the lifeblood of our economy. The only advertisers I knew were those who worked for us, not for a company like McDonalds, Coke, Nike or any other massive corporation that could afford to hire legions of advertising experts.
Instead we saw small, local businesses take on massive ad campaigns, often in languages they didn't speak. For instance, our company spent upwards of 20 hours a day on our own local television station advertising. In other words, we ran a full-fledged advertising operation.

These days, advertising still matters, but it no longer holds the crucial monopoly it once did. The Internet, which allows companies to advertise in a much more creative and targeted manner, is also slowly taking advertising's place. As this economy continues to shrink and the Internet grows, advertising will shrink even more.

So how to stop wasting time and money on advertising when the Internet is here to stay and the people who buy your product are on the Internet every day?
1. Check who is advertising on your website.
2. Check if it's a paid ad.
3. Keep the costs of advertising under control.

What would you do if your company couldn't afford to pay to advertise on the Internet? There are a variety of ways to make the most of the advertising that's free. Keep your costs down by using search engines instead of expensive advertising.

Plugging in the home Georgina McGuiness had taken a long career break from journalism and she felt out of touch with the changes brought about by technology. She recounts here how she was able to transform the family home into an efficient workplace.
The home where I lived as a kid is now full of computer monitors, and every time my daughter wants to sit and use a computer I have to remind myself: ‘It’s your home!’
There are now a number of computer users in the family. Georgina’s husband, Simon, watches online video tutorials, and her other son is an enthusiast in the latest online gaming fads, spending hours a day playing the latest multiplayer game.
Georgina, in her new role as ‘media officer’ of the family home, has a different role. As a child, I remember having so much fun helping her decorate rooms and draw up plans for new rooms. Now, she has been charged with keeping an eye on technology. In particular, she monitors how the kids use technology, and reports on how the various websites she has registered her children use (e.g. Facebook).
Georgina admits she has been known to sit in the dining room with the TV turned on and watch videos of children playing a game, all while the parents are at work!
We’ve all heard it said that the best way to learn a skill is by doing it. Well, it seems that the best way to do anything is by doing it in front of people. This idea has been drilled into us all from a young age, with us becoming ‘experts’ on many topics as adults. For example, I remember

POWER DRESSING EVERY SUMMER the peacocks that roam free within Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire expose their magnificent trains to the critical and often disdainful gaze of the hens. They re-enact the mystery that tormented Charles Darwin to his dying day: how in this competitive world where nature as Tennyson said - is red in tooth and claw could birds have evolved such an obvious extravagance? The men and the women who run the show, however, know that the world must know just how peacock-like their bird has become. It is the last time the birds will ever be seen in their wild state, not even in cages but hanging from the walls of the park, which itself was named after the birds - who, until the arrival of Europeans in the 18th Century, had been regarded as vermin. But not only their wildness is being celebrated. The birds’ show will now undergo its final curtain call, an experience for which each of the park’s six performers have undergone extensive training and preparation. But before the curtain rises, a few minutes’ warning is provided by the show’s resident peacock, who gives a short message. “Don’t let the chickens get to you, they’re very aggressive,” he says, and then, with the precision of an actor, a warning shot is fired.

In just over three months time, we will see exactly what we feared when the show started - a peacock being shot.
In a further four weeks, we will witness the birth of the babies. Then there is the feeding of the babies, every two minutes at 10am and 12pm, for the first four weeks. If this is all not enough for you, then there is the constant sight of the hens pecking the peacocks to death every hour. At the end

NATURAL TALENTS In the mere seven million years since we humans separated from chimpanzees we haven’t had time to develop any differences: genetically we’re still more than 98 per cent identical to chimps. On this grand evolutionary scale whatever it is that separates humans from animals is a very recent development. We are no longer the most remarkable animals on the planet. Advertisement 
  
 'But now it's clear that the link with mental ability was strong enough to predict intelligence,' Professor Schiller added. 'Intelligence was present in the earliest hominins as early as six million years ago, and so we may already have an idea of its origin from something as recent as five million years ago.' 
  
 There are at least three species in which intelligence, like height and hair length, is a common trait across all of the population, but the researchers believe that the same kind of genetic similarity may be widespread across all species of early hominins. 
  
 This raises the tantalising possibility that intelligence may have developed through a shared history of interbreeding, rather than through the more common selective breeding methods favoured by modern humans. 
  
 The study is published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

Chewing gum culture It’s fashionable classless and Americans chew 12 million sticks of it a day. Discover how an ancient custom became big business. Chewing gum contains fewer than ten calories per stick but it is classified as a food and must therefore conform to the standards of the American Food and Drug Administration. This includes labelling, and limits the amount of sugar, salt and other additives that may be added to a gum. How it came to be Chewing gum has a fascinating history from the days of the Cherokee Indians, who were so addicted to the bitter flavor of Indian tobacco that they chewed it to ward off malaria, to the silent, unconscious practice of the Chinese who, in the 1850s, used gum as a way to get an afternoon break and relax. Today, gum is sold all over the world and in the United States it is estimated that 12 million sticks are chewed per day. The chew industry was initiated by a group of African men and women in the 1890s who saw the business potential in chewing gum as a way to make money, and they soon started exporting the product. But to maintain an accurate record of the growth of chewing gum, the industry created its own chewing gum industry association, the American Chewing Gum Association, which has since become one of the world’s leading gum manufacturers. The most common chewing gum in the United States is Lucky Strike, which is made in the United States and contains 85% gum. It’s easy to see how the chewing gum industry spread. Chewing gum is so enjoyable that adults will chew 2.5 sticks per day and that’s without dieting. There is a large population in the United States that is sedentary, working in offices or sitting in class, which means that chewing gum is

Beginner Takes All Even before it was published The Horse Whisperer was the hottest book of the year. A first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans it has earned its author record-breaking sums. He talks here about his inspiration and his triumph The first months of the year were not kind to Nicholas Evans screenwriter producer and aspiring director. His debut novel was a flop, the press hated him and his movie rights had not been sold yet. In December of the previous year, the book was withdrawn from print in the USA after an uproar and two lawsuits. It was withdrawn because it included some rather graphic images of horseflesh which many objected to. At the beginning of April, the novel The Horse Whisperer went through its second reissue. In this new edition Evans added a chapter about the success of the book and the movie rights had been sold for 100 million dollars. This was one year to the day since his first book was published. The film rights had been purchased in 1983 but the distribution company pulled out after the first round of litigation with one of its directors. The rights were not sold again for the next seven years. Nicholas Evans went on to write two further novels. The first one, released in 2003 was a big flop and it was withdrawn from publication after a few issues. The sequel, released in 2004, is regarded by many to be the finest of his works and it was even selected as a best book of the year. The film version of the second book came out in 2012 and was highly successful. Evans and his team also started to direct movies. They made an impressive debut at the 2012 Cannes Film Festival with the film The Devil Inside and recently they filmed the adaptation of the acclaimed novel The Girl Who Leapt Through Time. THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER A. Tamburlaine the Great Marlowe’s ten-act epic about the all-conquering warrior can seem never-ending but it emerges as one of the most thrilling nights of the year in Terry Hands’ staging. He has hacked great chunks from the text and offers a production that combines the glories of Marlowe’s play with an exhilarating speed and physicality.
For most of the opening two hours of this show, the stage is a river, with actors rushing and tumbling over the rapids and under the waves as they perform their various parts in the fight that ensues. The audience is at the mercy of their rapid moves and frantic choreography, with the pace constantly ratcheted up. They are thrown from high places and hurled through the air at will – or so it seems.
There are some impressive performances but it’s a frantic hour with the action constantly speeding up and the plot never reaching a happy conclusion.
It’s also a big, theatrical show – in fact it would have worked well as a one-man show had Terry Hands stuck to it. But as an event, his production is a spectacular treat that is hard to look away from.
When you have this in mind, and consider the scale of the show and the physical challenges that are inherent in it, it’s easy to see why Mr Spencers decided to tell Marlowe’s story as a saga.
Somewhere in London, Mr Spencer was one of the most dangerous men in England.
