The end of print may take some time Peter Preston Transition. It’s a pleasant word and a calming concept. Change may frighten some and challenge others. But transition means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future. Unless that is it is newspapers’ ‘transition’ to the online world an uncertain and highly uncomfortable process – because frankly it may not be a process at all. ‘Print is dying’ is a very uninteresting and tired expression – or is it? It has been around for 100 years, which is longer than it has been on newsprint. If newspapers’ demise doesn’t take us by surprise (and we mustn’t allow the big advertising corporations to have that great feeling), it would certainly lead to its demise. Newspapers have been a constant part of our lives since 1845. During the second world war (or the ‘Great War’ as they call it now), it helped with the survival of the nation and its people. It also provided a vital link between all the world’s news and gave us a much more rounded knowledge of the world we live in. But it also made life on the streets more dangerous, because newspapers were ‘in your face’, with their sensational stories, which could give the police a lot of new evidence and help them with their investigation. But now they are ‘in your face’, no more. Newspapers’ demise means a shift from ‘in your face’ to ‘in your desk’. But then people will have to find a new way to find out what’s going on, if the news from their newspaper is not enough. It will not be the only way. We have television and the internet, but let’s face it, with all that available, it is easy to

Take Five Careers Rebecca Cripps meets five women who discuss their different professions: the highlights the drawbacks and their typical working day. A. THE BRAIN SURGEON Name: Anne Age: 34 ANNE'S DAY "I get up at 6.30am go the gym at 7am get to work by 8am and start operating at 8.30am. I work in The Brain Surgeon's Department in a state hospital in the US. I like to help people get rid of their neuro-tumours and epilepsy. I deal with the medical doctors, nurses, the patient and their families. I work 24 hours a day, 7 days a week but I never take a day off. I spend my whole day in an office. It's a stressful job. At the end of the day I do a good job because it helps people get rid of their problems." THE PHYSICIST Age: 42 PAUL'S DAY "Today, I am with my husband Paul. We are going to the supermarket. At eight am, he puts the kids to bed and I take out the groceries. After that, I take care of the house. I do the dishes, do the laundry and do everything that is necessary. I also do some shopping, with my husband and the kids, before going back to the office. "At seven in the evening, I put the kids to bed and go back to my office. I work 24 hours a day, 7 days a week and I never take a day off. I spend my entire day in an office. It's a stressful job. The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from perfectly crafted furniture Joanna Watt meets him Charles Hurst gives the impression of being a man in a hurry. I arrive at his workshop tucked under a railway arch in East London and am greeted with a quick handshake and the words: 'Well fire away then!' Whether this brusqueness is real or a front hiding a shy streak is not immediately apparent. He tells me he has a background in medicine, is a skilled wood-carver, and his workshop is well appointed. He cuts straight and clean lines in his wooden pieces but his wood is thin. I am impressed that he makes furniture without nails, though the work seems to be slow. As I am not a woodworking expert I can only begin to appreciate these skills. His handiwork is certainly good but not amazing. The most impressive thing about his work is that he makes it with only two hands. There are two assistants, Michael and Mike. Michael cuts the oak that Hurst chooses and Mike cleans up the dust and dings. 'I was made to look after you,' he says. There is no doubt in my mind that I need to ask Michael how Hurst makes the furniture. He looks slightly annoyed that I have interrupted his work to ask. 'The man is a genius and I don't need to be reminded,' Michael replies. He gives me a final tip on the art of wooden furniture making: 'Hurt yourself and you are done for.' Solar Survivor Charles Clover ventures inside Britain’s most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire is full of surprises. The first is Britain’s least-known ancient cathedral Southwell Minster celebrated by writers of an environmental disposition for the pagan figures of ‘green’ men which medieval craftsmen carved into the decoration in its thirteenth-century chapter house.
The second surprise is the home itself. A ‘coffin house’ built between 1585 and 1590 Southwell was a member of a religious sect led by Robert Howard, the Earl of Chester, later King Henry VIII. Its most famous member was Charles I – and its most controversial was its last and greatest housekeeper. Her name was Elizabeth Tudor and her legend is a perfect match for Southwell.
When Henry VIII died in 1547, the Earl of Leicester and his sons became sovereign. King Henry VIII's famous family at a party celebrating the death of his brother, Henry VIII.
The Earl of Leicester wished to become monarch himself but firstly he needed to marry and, as in Shakespeare’s famous play Henry VIII – The Talents, he found his match. He had been living with and raising his daughter, Anne Boleyn at Southwell for eleven years when he succeeded in getting an order from the Pope to marry his cousin Anne Boleyn.
So, at Southwell he and Anne Boleyn lived on a huge estate and in a spectacular church. Southwell became a model community for the aristocracy and for Catholics and, of course, there was Elizabeth Tudor.
At first Elizabeth had no contact with the world outside her own home. As she got older and had a daughter of her own, however, she began to realise that her life would have a greater impact if she could connect with people. She started to learn

Ancient Chinese medicine in the West? Acupuncture is two thousand years old. It comes from the traditional Chinese system of medicine that includes herbalism massage diet manipulation and exercise. It is used to treat many different conditions but acupuncture’s role in treating pain has received most attention by doctors in the West. However, the medical system of Chinese medicine is not limited to pain and injury. It has the potential to treat mental illnesses from depression to obsessive compulsive disorder.
Ancient Chinese medicine did not rely on drugs or alcohol to treat illness. Instead, it treated the symptoms of the disease and avoided the causes. This meant that it helped to reduce pain and stress. People suffered from less pain due to this. There was less chance of being addicted to drugs. Chinese medicine is not the only type of medicine that can treat illness. Traditional Chinese medicine incorporates other types of therapy to provide maximum benefit to the patient. However, the emphasis was on dealing with the cause of the disease, not the symptoms. This meant that the treatment needed to be non-surgical, gentle and non-drug based.
Medicine was always based on observation. If you were sick you could tell your doctor about it and he would prescribe some sort of treatment. For example, if you were having severe pain in your leg you could tell the doctor that it hurts when you stand up and when you sit down. He would then prescribe some painkillers. This is not the case any more. Today’s medicine relies on controlled experiments and clinical trials. It will try a number of treatments to see what works best. This approach can take a long time but is necessary if we are to have a better understanding of how to treat disease.
It is amazing how much medicine has changed over the last two thousand years.

The December cover of Capitol Magazine featured Clay Carter looking rich and handsome in his expensive Armani suit. Inside there were pictures of him playing with a dog (borrowed from Rodney) standing proudly in empty courtrooms washing his new Porsche and standing on board his new boat in the Bahamas. This didn't impress Paul Simon at all.
Carter is clearly a bit of a hypocrite - it's clear he's just as happy and comfortable on a budget as he is with a big, expensive car, yacht and party clothes.
"I don't think it's really about who you're wearing, it's about who you're with," he said in a 2007 interview with Billboard. "I think people think that because you're a celebrity, you're automatically wealthy. And I disagree. I'm not wealthy. I've got a good job. I'm comfortable."
So does this make Paul Simon a hypocrite? Or is it a valid criticism of his lifestyle? In a way, it's both.
Firstly, Simon is a celebrity with lots of wealth and a huge fan base. By "having it all", he doesn't necessarily mean he has more than he needs.
"As far as I’m concerned, my private life, I have no time for that. I’ve got enough problems. I don’t have time to go around getting myself into more trouble," Simon said in a 2004 interview with Elle US.
"I live a relatively normal life, and I’m not going to complain about it."

A. 'I actually look rather good in jeans. So I rarely wear them. I don't want to get mixed up with the wrong sort of person.’ So runs the logic of Isabel 'our heroine’ in this refreshingly zany novel. An art student of 31 devotee of historical romances she seeks Mr Right but is concerned lest her knobbly knees ruin her chances. The story begins at the start of the French Revolution and is played out through the characters and situations which the reader, in a way, is experiencing. Isabel is caught up in the political upheaval as is her friend and fellow artist, Jacques. Their housekeeper, Madame Degraine, is equally as captivated by the revolutionaries and her dreams of escaping to Switzerland. She finds refuge in one of the rooms in the house and the story begins with her, but her escape does not last long. The revolutionaries come for her too and Isabel must use her wit and charm to get out of their clutches, even if it means being burned alive. At last she comes to the aid of Jacques, a political refugee, who is just as eager to escape from the political turmoil as Isabel. The three join forces, escaping into the countryside and finding work as labourers but in the midst of all this Isabel meets her old lover, François. Isabel, Jacques and Francois are together again but their happiness is short-lived when Isabel’s mother-in-law, the Duchess of Artois, unexpectedly appears. She comes to the house and takes possession of Isabel’s house with the intention of evicting François, who she considers a criminal in her son’s eyes and Isabel has nowhere to go, and Francois is arrested. The trio is brought to the city council who are intent on executing both Jacques and François in order to make way for the rich Marquis de Lalaing

Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives asleep. It seems certain therefore that sleep has a vital function. However what that function might be is still in debate. Scientists are far from being in agreement about precisely why so much of our precious time is given over to sleep. Some studies suggest that sleep helps to build memory, some studies suggest that sleep helps to maintain mental health, and still others suggest that sleep helps us to recover from the stresses of the day. Here we take a look at the most commonly accepted theories and examine some of the limitations of some of them. In particular, we take a closer look at the influence of circadian rhythm on sleep duration. 

Sleep, or at least the time that you are asleep, is critical for normal human functioning, it is thought. During sleep, the body produces a number of hormones, such as adrenaline (which contributes to our heart beat); cortisol (which helps to regulate our blood sugar levels); and histamine (which regulates the immune system), which helps to fight infection. So if a person is unable to sleep properly, these things cannot function properly. If you are reading this article you must be aware that not sleeping is not something that can be fixed overnight. If you cannot manage to be satisfied with just eight hours a night, you should make an effort to improve the quality of your sleep. 

Now as for why people sleep so much... There is no clear evidence, yet, about why we sleep so much. Perhaps the answer lies in our internal clock. We don't have a single "internal clock". Our circadian rhythm, the biological clock of our internal body, controls our sleep, wake and appetite cycles. The biological clock of the internal body is thought to synchronize with our external

Is your office working ok? Fresh air and the right chairs are the key to a happy healthy workforce according to a new survey. We went to four contrasting offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments. On our expert panel were a building health consultant; an ergonomist who studies people’s working conditions; and an occupational psychologist. They all agreed that healthy and happy employees are more productive and happier at work. 

The survey results show that the first thing people look for when choosing an office is its fresh air intake. Just under half of the respondents (47.8%) said this was an important factor for choosing a workspace, just ahead of air conditioning (43.2%) and Wi-Fi (42.1%).

One of our expert panelists found this to be the most surprising, finding that a good amount of people work in unheated offices, in fact one in three (32.7%) work in unheated offices all year round and the other half (57%) don’t bother. He also added that the first thing he’d do when choosing an office is to look for an open plan office so that people can see people across the floor.

We also asked the panelists about what type of environment they would rather work in and, interestingly, our building had the least amount of employees who wanted an open plan office. Only 14% of the respondents said they would prefer one instead of a split plan. On the other hand, the most preferred environment was one with a cubicle. 

The building health and ergonomics consultant on the panel said it was clear that when people are working in an open plan office they can’t get enough fresh air and are too close to their colleagues, they tend to ‘hear�

THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING I thought everyone would be pleased but one of my colleagues was absolutely furious. ‘What do you mean?’ she raged. ‘If it was that easy why didn’t you stop years ago?’ I suppose my inability to explain how one afternoon I had been a packet-a-day life-long smoker and four hours later I was not was faintly irritating. Maybe I should have explained, if only to make sure she did not continue to be angry. However, I was now looking at a life time of abstinence, a lifetime of not having to worry if I was running low on nicotine. ‘What will you do without smoking?’ ‘I’ll live. I’ll lead a normal life,’ I said. It was true – I was not depressed and was no longer suffering with nicotine withdrawal. ‘It’s so wonderful to be able to eat an apple or chocolate. I miss all the junk food,’ she protested, ‘but I’m not going to be able to afford it.’ I agreed that I would not be able to buy unhealthy food for a while and we decided that smoking could not be stopped completely. My colleague had one more question. ‘Why do you say you are addicted to nicotine?’ ‘I smoked a packet a day for ten years,’ I said, ‘I was addicted, you see. There was no way to stop the habit.’ She seemed not to understand the point I was trying to make. Then it came to me: I remembered the advice from a friend who had tried quitting smoking. He had said: ‘If you’ve had one cigarette, don’t have another. You’ll only be tempted to smoke when your back is against the wall.

Writing by hand and on screen Dr Johnson maintained that ‘what is written without effort is in general read without pleasure’. The converse is that good writing comes hard. Looking back though my handwritten school essays I was surprised at how few crossings-out they contained. Today I would have rewritten them five times over. To be in the minority of the English-speaking world, however, is to be in a minority of life.
This doesn’t mean that every passage must be written with the help of a screenwriter (although the advantages of their script can’t be overstated), but the idea that it’s an essential skill to have – in fact a necessary one - seems a strong claim. I still do most of my writing on paper, but I’ve written (in fact still do) quite a few screenplays, most recently the BBC TV adaptation of Michael Morpurgo’s biography of Charles Dickens. I’m constantly amazed by the quality of scripts I get in response to my e-mail or phone correspondence with script writers, including some of the best I know.
I’m also a regular user of the screenwriter toolkit provided by my favourite writers and publishers: for my first draft I use the version of screenwriting software, Storyline, produced by Hollywood veteran Robert Zemeckis. For the final draft I use the free version of Screenwriter for Windows by Jonathan Kasdan and his company WME.
These are not professionals, nor have they had years of training and education behind them. Some are still working in their twenties. I’d be very surprised if anyone could answer the question ‘can you write a good screenplay?’ convincingly, but if they can, then I’

Philadelphia Avenue I headed down Philadelphia Avenue on the odd-numbered side. The dusk had deepened the humidity thickened into a palpable prickly drizzle that lent my walk a heightened feeling of sheltered stealth. A few blocks later I reached what appeared to be my destination: a little, brick building with a few boarded up windows, a single, ornate doorway that glistened in the fading light from the surrounding lamp-posts. Looking for a place to eat I approached the door, which was propped slightly ajar. ‘Hello,’ I said. ‘It’s me.’ ‘Can I help you?’ It was a small man, barely over six feet tall. ‘I’d like some food,’ I said. ‘I’ve been looking all around. Do you mind if I wait for someone?’ ‘No problem. Go right in,’ I said, with a small smile, and opened the door. ‘Would you like a lemonade or hot chocolate?’ ‘No, thanks.’ The man entered into the warm, moist, cozy interior. He was warm and comfortable. There was a soft sound, soft enough to be almost asleep, of the shutters of the old brick building, and the soft whisper of distant rain. He seemed almost at home. He was still warm, and I could feel the rich, sooty aroma of the freshly baked bread and scones. And the rich scent of homemade preserves that hung from the counter, dripping in a glass bowl from the old glass windows that looked over the street. I was hungry

Einstein Stop anyone in the street and ask them to name a scientist and the chances are they’ll think of Albert Einstein. His face is used to advertise products with intellectual connotations from computers to encyclopaedias. So why not advertise with his name? Because he didn’t. He lived a long and active life but is mostly remembered for his theories of relativity. Even though there was no conclusive evidence to back these theories up. They still seem very relevant today. However, there is good evidence that his ideas were indeed tested and proved with some success. Here are just five facts about Einstein you may not have known before.
1. In 1905 he moved to Berlin from Basel and set up his own business.
2. In 1908 he moved to Bern to work for the French mathematician and physicist Henri Poincaré.
3. In 1910 Einstein and his brother left Paris to go to Switzerland because they were worried about their father who was mentally ill.
4. In 1912 he went to Berlin to complete a book about his theories of relativity.
5. In 1921 Einstein and several other scientists formed the Association for the Study of Special Relativity.

This was the first time Albert Einstein actually went public with his theories of relativity.
He was only 28 years old when he decided to do this as he was becoming very sick and tired of not being taken seriously. He had also been working in Switzerland for a while on his theories.
Einstein made an impact on both fields of science. In the field of physics he created the theory of special relativity and this allowed for all of the above. His theories were the first to be tested and proved scientifically. His theory on

Amateur Astronomy Many things have changed in astronomy over the past half-century. Until about 30 years ago there was a great shortage of charts and catalogues. Telescopic equipment was limited and there were few books on practical astronomy. Today the range of off-the-shelf telescopes and equipment covers almost everything one could need. And there are vast numbers of new astronomical books and catalogues. There has also been an astonishing expansion in our knowledge of the physical processes at work in the universe. It is no longer necessary to rely on the theory of general relativity to describe the vast array of physical phenomena in the universe, as was the case when Einstein first proposed it 60 years ago. These advances in understanding have led us to the development of more complex observational techniques, such as gravitational waves, high-energy cosmic rays, black holes, neutron stars and supermassive black holes, among others. Since the advent of these new observational techniques, some new and exciting new astronomy questions have emerged. Astronomers are beginning to explore how the universe works, and how it evolved in the early universe. This involves both looking into the early history of the universe and studying the more recent history of the universe, as well as investigating the present state of our universe. This is all leading to a more in-depth understanding of the history of the universe, and how it has unfolded. There is much uncertainty in the physical laws governing our universe, and the study of these laws is therefore a crucial element of understanding the present and past of the universe, as well as planning the future of astronomy. Another important aim of astronomy is to study the properties of cosmic rays, which play a major role in the origin and evolution of life in our universe. We must understand how particles of matter, including carbon and oxygen, react to cosmic rays. As is well

Art In modern times - more and more over the course of the last two hundred years - we have come to speak as though every artist had to rebel against the art of his contemporaries. Art is praised in terms of being unique revolutionary shocking even. We feel good about admiring the artist whose work no one appreciated a hundred years ago. This is especially true about contemporary artists. However, sometimes the artist has become over-hyped to the point that they are often ridiculed - the artist themselves are usually forced to defend their work against the critics. In fact, sometimes there's nothing wrong with criticizing the art of an artist, so long as we don't forget that the criticism has to have substance, which is more important than just the "flavor" of the criticism. We feel the same about music. We are quite fond of saying "I like your music", but more important than the music is the artist. It's really important that an artist gets out of his way and starts showing that he's got something interesting to say and that he can actually develop and change. So, when we say that "we like your music", we're actually expressing our sincere opinion. However, people often think that if they like what we like then they must like it too. When we hear about a new great rock band, we often hear a lot of the same songs and we often hear the same band's sound. It doesn't mean we must like it or that it has to be our type of music, but we can be critical of it and know that it's not an important thing. So, when we say, "your music is great", we're not just being nice to you, we're also expressing our genuine opinion. Of course, we may not know that you wrote a book or a movie or a song

Fashion Fashion is often seen as a modern phenomenon entirely dependent upon nineteenth- and twentieth-century capitalism for its development. Most historians of fashion are at pains to point out though that fashion at least in the sense of style and design has a very long history. They often take the rise of the market and mercantile trade in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries as their starting point. However, the history of fashion is also made up of earlier episodes of social interaction. There were social rituals which were also crucial to the way we see and experience fashion. There is therefore the need for our study of fashion to be as much a social one as it is an archaeological one. However, this need not prevent us from looking at a fashion situation in past societies. The history of fashion can help us to make a better understanding of past societies. And it can provide us with models by which to study the present fashion situation. This is because it is fashion in the past which enabled us to imagine the present-day fashion situation. In particular, fashion offers us with a rich historical background which makes it suitable for analysis by social scientists and archaeologists. Furthermore, fashion is a very important social process, both in the past and in the present. This is because fashion is a social phenomenon and its impact on society depends upon the social structure. If we wish to better understand society, we need to know how and why fashion occurs. This is because if we want to understand society better, we need to know how people interact and socialise. In fact, it is the interaction between social groups that is key to the emergence of different social structures. So, to understand how people socialise, we need to know how people socialise in the past. We can use this knowledge to get a better understanding of how we can better understand society. Furthermore, by knowing how people socialise, we can

Metals It may have been a wish for self-adornment that aroused the interest of Stone Age people in metals. Sitting by the side of a river waiting for a fish to come within a spears throw or just idling away a moment one of our early ancestors might have happened upon a shiny yellow pebble and plucked it off the river bed. These small pieces of stone would then be smeared with honey and baked for an enjoyable snack. It would probably have been a rare find to encounter such a pebble, but one might not expect that an ancestor would actually carve it into a weapon. Some tools were certainly carved with great skill; stone axes and swords were probably used, and this was a valuable skill. It would have been an opportunity to show off and it would have been a means of survival. It was an early use of the hammer and chisel. There is an assumption that the tools were found in small flocks, such as a rock pile, or left by people. This was to be a common activity of early settlers; they would gather wood for cooking and make a fire and when they left they would leave some with the birds. Many would have left the pebbles in their tool kit in an attempt to impress their mates. A very early use of the chisel and hammer, probably with some type of wood. These were probably made from trees such as cedars and oak. We know that the first tool could have been a stick used to crush bones. However, it is important that we do not read too much into this as some evidence is a bit weak. Some have suggested that it was probably stone that we find in stone age graves. We do not know and this is an area where there is still much uncertainty. It was probably not metal that made the graves, but stone. It

The Vienna Assignment I was in Vienna to take photographs. That was generally the reason I was anywhere then. Photographs were more than my livelihood. They were part of my life. The way light fell on a surface never failed to tug at my imagination. My favorite moments were when it fell into the right light and the color, depth and texture in a photograph were as rich as life itself. But when I took photographs, I could never have imagined that any of these photographs would be one of the most iconic images of our time.
My first assignment in Vienna was in 1974. It was a year of transition in this city. As war was raging all around the world, Vienna was the perfect place to find some peace and calm. There was so much to photograph and so little time, so I took my camera and started walking around, looking for light, trying to get a shot of something I saw every day. But the best light, for me, was when I caught the eye of one of my friends who was working in a shop on the other side of the street. In our brief conversation, I found out he was a fashion photographer. A few months later, he called me on the phone. “I have a job for you,” he said. I had been a student since high school and had taken quite a few fashion assignments, but this was something new. He explained the photograph he was looking for and then gave me a few minutes to prepare. We left to meet the client and went down the street a few minutes later.
I walked into the shop to meet him. He had photographed a wedding in our town and had called up to see if I wanted to model for him. It had been a

Enough Sleep? Tiredness it is often claimed has become the modern condition. As the richer busier countries have grown so sleeplessness and anxiety have also grown in the popular psyche. Research in the USA has found 40 million Americans to be chronically affected and some recent best-selling novels in Britain have featured insomniacs as protagonists or sleep-research laboratories as their settings. But does sleep really mean what it used to? Are sleep-deprivation disorders a new disease category? What do sleep-deprivation disorders actually involve? Do we really need seven to nine hours a night? What other health benefits of sleep can we claim to derive from longer sleep time? These are some of the questions which have been put to the experts who have examined the evidence in this area. The result has been a new book which sets out a case for a new classification of sleep-deprivation disorder based on the number of hours people sleep. Sleep is generally understood to have a circadian rhythm, with a biological rhythm arising from the internal body clock in mammals. It is generally agreed that sleep cycles in mammals are in a 24-hour cycle and each of the 24 hours includes a roughly three to five hours of daily wakefulness and a roughly five to six hours of nightly sleep. The amount of sleep the individual needs varies with the stage in life, with a minimum amount needed for maximum energy levels. This is why it is important to get a minimum of eight hours per night for a normal adult. But as most people grow older their sleep needs increase. In an attempt to measure the amount of sleep people need to feel rested, the International Sleep Education Society created the Standards of International Sleep Research (SI-SERS) which are defined as the total sleep duration required to be fully relaxed. SI-SERS can be divided into two classes: short sleep and normal sleep.

Air-conditioning There is a chill in the air at Cannons Gym a favourite lunch-time haunt for City of London workers. To deal with this summer’s unusually high temperatures the fitness centre has gone overboard with the air-conditioning. So much so in fact that at quiet times the gym feels like somewhere in the Arctic. And that’s before any of the other indoor spaces are added to the bill. The result is a sweaty, over-the-top environment that I’d happily sacrifice for better summer weather. However, it’s been going on for so long that it’s a bit of a given that more of this sort of over-the-topness is on the way. To its credit, Cannons has decided to have a look and see if it can make something more palatable. It’s doing this with the opening of its third gym. The first two are already popular – and there are more due in the autumn. This one, due to open next April, will focus on strength training and offer high-intensity workouts. And with that kind of thing comes a very important and overdue adjustment to the way the gym feels. You will get a wider range of workout equipment in this one. Gone will be the high-pressure equipment on the ellipticals and machines. It will be more of a gym in the modern sense – a place where fitness is a part of everyday life, a place where you can go if you want to do some basic cardiovascular work, some strength training and some light weight-lifting. There will be no machines or ellipticals in this gym. What you will find is a much wider choice of equipment. And that is because as an over-45s market Cannons must do something about its reputation for being a boring gym

THE WELL I had read somewhere that from a sufficiently deep hole one could see the stars if the day were clear. I had persuaded you to help me with my scheme; you watched eyes wide fist to mouth as I winched up the well bucket steadied it on the wall and then climbed in. We made it to the top and I turned the bucket upside down as high as I dared, looking for anything that might give me an edge. “Hey man, that’s a good idea, but the water’s too cold!” I heard you say, and then I saw it: a small pool that looked warm enough for a drink. “You’re right, the water’s still just right.” I took a swallow of the cool water and then turned the bucket upside down in search of something else, but I had to leave quickly, as the sun was rising. Your laughter, as I left, gave me the boost I needed. It was at that moment when I started walking in a straight line toward where you stood. I saw you the whole way and it made me smile. I kept walking until I got to your house. At the back of the yard I saw that the pool was full. I heard you call back to me, “Look, there’s a star on my shoe!” “Yeah, you’ve caught the star light!” I answered. We ran up the steps to your porch and there, just at the top of the porch steps, was a brilliant shining star. “I know you’re right, I feel it. I can see it. I will be rich!” I said, as you shook my hand tightly.

Ralph unlocked the door to his let and as he entered the dark motionless hall experienced that momentary qualm of ownership which even after three years still lightly besieged him sometimes when he returned alone at the end of the day.

"Hello." He said to the open door.

"What?" The door said back.

"Hello." He repeated.

The doorknob rattled a little in its silence.

"Hello." Again, the door answered.

And a silence enveloped them, which remained till the man in the suit left and the door swung closed on him.

Ralph wondered whether anyone else had ever felt such a strange, almost personal, awareness of their own mortality. The feeling persisted as he drove home the rest of the afternoon. 

When he returned to his home, he found that his wife, Ruth, was waiting for him. She was tired but had made an elaborate supper and would have gone to bed by now had he not been so insistent.

"I just couldn't wait," she told him. "As it happens I'm a big fan of yours."

"Why do you think that's?"

"I've seen all your pictures. Your work is just so... real. It's... "

Heritage The true meaning and significance of heritage is that it gives people and communities a genuine sense of connection with the past. Obviously we feel connected to our personal heritage usually we know who and what our grandparents were and we will have heard stories about how they lived. Heritage gives the community pride in its surroundings and a link to its past.
Heritage in itself is not a valuable asset in itself, it’s not like a fossil or a rock, rather it’s a legacy. It’s more important for it’s heritage to be preserved and protected for future generations and to share it with others than to get money or benefits from it. There are benefits of keeping heritage, for example it helps to reduce pollution.
Heritage preservation is one of the main strategies of many organisations. It helps to educate people and to develop their knowledge of heritage. It is not only beneficial in preserving heritage but also for the promotion of tourism. It helps to preserve our heritage and keep people interested in it.
I think that heritage is good as it contributes to the growth of the economy. It brings the community together and gives hope and positive energy. It gives people a sense of belonging and pride in their heritage. It keeps our identity alive.
A heritage day is a great occasion to let people know about the heritage and appreciate it. Heritage is a source of inspiration for many other activities. Heritage has a great importance in our society. Without heritage the future will be different.
Heritage should be kept alive. People should not damage it. I think that heritage should be protected and preserved.
For people who like heritage and want to help preserve it for future generations; you can contact the World Heritage Centre and you can write

Othello The transfer to London from Stratford of an exceptional production of Shakespeare’s play Othello allows me to make amends for an unfair review that I wrote when the show opened last spring. Back then I complained that Ray Fearon was too young to play the title role and I was guilty of running down his acting. I felt that the play itself was not that great a piece but fearon and his co-star, Mark Rylance, had a fine time onstage as Othello and I was pleased to see that they succeeded in portraying the character’s humanity. At the time I also thought that the set was a bit small and did not offer any visual interest. Now I am inclined to think otherwise. At the present moment I am not particularly impressed by this new production but the actors deserve some credit and the staging is certainly more exciting than that of last spring. Director Philip James is giving the actors ample time onstage and giving them the chance to deliver memorable speeches. He also has done a fine job of creating a convincing and exciting setting. However, I still do not entirely get what Othello’s problem is. I do not think the plot is particularly complex and there is no doubt that Shakespeare left plenty of room for misinterpretations. Othello, therefore, has to make up his own mind before he can make an informed choice. In addition to his own conscience, Othello also has to make sure he can take up the challenge imposed by his wife Desdemona. The latter is a dangerous person and does not always keep her word. However, in this play, she is clearly an aggressor and, thus, deserves punishment. The story thus goes forward. Othello can commit suicide after having saved the life of Desdemona but at this point we

The Wrong Country Uncle chose for them a package holiday at a very reasonable price: a flight from Gatwick Airport twelve nights in Venice the fairyland city in the Pensione Concordia. When Keith and Dawne went together to the travel agency to make the booking the counter clerk explained that the other members of that particular package were a school group from the south coast all of them learning Italian. In a little while the group got there and it was impossible to find a seat so it turned out that they could not all go together. The problem was solved because they had the ticket to the first and last flight but still they had to go to the airport every evening. Uncle Dave told Dawne that they should be at the airport before departure and that he would walk to the departure gate with them. When they arrived at the airport they saw the school group arrive and was very disappointed because one of them was a great friend of Keith and he was afraid to tell his friends that he was going to miss the flight, because his friends had to come with him to the airport in the evening every single day. When Keith went to walk to the departure gate Uncle Dave took him behind a counter and told him to get a room for the next twenty-four hours, they were there. When Keith was alone with the counter clerk she told him that she had a boyfriend. Keith didn't ask who he was or what her name was, but she said she was always jealous of him and they could only talk to each other behind his back. Keith knew that he was dreaming, so he kept calm and told her that he would find a room. Uncle Dave told him he was going to find something for her. When Keith asked about rooms in this strange hotel she told him that they had a lot of beds but Uncle Dave was going to have to go around the whole building to find a room for her

Observing Lions In the popular imagination lions hunting for food present a marvel of group choreography: in the dying light of sunset a band of stealthy cats springs forth from the shadows like trained assassins and surrounds its unsuspecting prey. The lions seem to be archetypal social animals rising above petty dissension to work together towards a common goal - in this case their next meal. Although they are animals that share a close association with people, the lion has a curious absence from our popular imagination. For several reasons. First, it is not considered an important species by some. For instance, while a human has around 1 in 15 billion chances to be killed by a lion, that of a lioness is one in 3 billion; for a lion hunting for food, the odds are about 1 in 6 billion. Second, to the wider public lions are a menace, a symbol of poverty and instability. Indeed, some see the great cat as a living symbol of Africa's ills, a reminder of how wild and violent the continent can be. Advertisement.
The animals, however, are as capable of thinking as any other brain. They are not stupid or moronic as humans tend to imagine, says Dr Nesher. 'Lions need to be fed, they need to eat. And they can actually think about what they are going to do next,' he explains. Advertisement.
One of the most important tasks a wild carnivore can perform is to find prey. A lion, for example, can use all of its senses - seeing, hearing, smelling, feeling - to pick its target. This can take a long time.
'Every day you might have a big hunt, and you might spend several hours searching for the same prey,' Dr Nesher says. 'It's an incredible amount of time.'

Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged married couple for a 501-day round trip to Mars. Applicants must be physically and emotionally robust. This will be the profile of the very first Martian astronauts if multi-millionaire Dennis Tito’s plans to launch a capsule on 5 January 2018 actually lead to fruition. Tito’s plan for the mission, named Project Mars (Mars Orbiter Mission), has a team of experts and designers working hard to put this dream trip together. The final product will include a three-man crew and a spacecraft, plus various spacecraft hardware, instruments and the crew’s daily routine. It will likely have a duration of about 4.5 months at an altitude of about 200km above Mars, and about 30 hours per day of exploration. Although not required, such people would obviously bring along all kinds of science instruments and equipment. The astronauts will be living in a habitat that will be mounted on the lander and the crew module that is expected to land on Mars after the arrival of the Mars Orbiter. The crew module will carry the astronauts, their equipment, spare parts, and food. A second habitat (for the scientists and engineers) will be attached to the lander and will stay at a higher altitude. If there is enough money left over, the project will also have the possibility of including a Mars landing vehicle and its crew of four. These four humans will live on the lander for a total of about 6 months. It will be interesting to see what sort of equipment is required for an expedition to Mars, but I guess there will not be too many differences between the equipment used for the moon mission and the Mars mission. I would also imagine the amount of science and research needed for an expedition to Mars will be even more than that needed for

Garbage in garbage out Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems environmentally sound and economically sensible. It may not be. Some rituals of modern domestic living vary little throughout the developed world. One such is the municipal refuse collection: at regular intervals rubbish bags or the contents of rubbish bins disappear into the bowels of a special lorry and are carried away to the local tip.
In many American cities the local rubbish man is paid a low salary and the amount of his wages is fixed. The residents of a neighbourhood then collect the rubbish that their man has been taking away. The amount he is paid is fixed. This means that, in many cases, even if you are a resident of the neighbourhood it pays not to clean up after your man. There is some advantage to this system as well, however: the more rubbish a locality has, the less need there is to send out a rubbish man and the less time and money is devoted to the task.
The local rubbish man is required to collect every kind of rubbish, including, of course, garden and rubbish cans, litter, etc. In rural areas it may also include wood waste and old tyres. He is paid in accordance with the volume of refuse he removes. In city areas he may be paid by the cubic yard, but it is usually cheaper to collect it in pieces.
In many American cities there are some exceptions to this rule: for example, in New York City the residents are required to pay a small levy on the amount of rubbish they generate, and so, through their council, to provide rubbish collection.
In most American cities the garbage man also collects the recyclable material. You could easily imagine a future in which the households in your neighbourhood collected only recyclable materials. The garbage man would collect only the other rubbish and the council would collect only recyclable materials.

Goat Racing I was about to witness goat racing. Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I was fighting my way through ice-cream vans hordes of people food stalls and hot music singeing my eardrums. Even though the general movement was towards the racecourse I elbowed my way through the crowds in an effort to get a good pitch. I soon saw the start line, the crowd was still very packed but this would soon quieten down, the crowd now was much smaller and had only one intention the race. I had been watching the race for years, I have seen the runners and seen them getting closer and closer to the finish line. At about ten minutes before the start of the race the announcer said that it was time to get ready, the music was loud and the marshalls were calling the runners to a start. I had to shout out for the marshalls to wait for me as my glasses were still in my purse. I ran to the end of the race where the marshalls were located and they had gathered. The marshalls got down off their stands and began walking the course calling for the runners. I ran up to them and asked if I could run with them, they seemed surprised to say the least and they just smiled, it was very friendly to have a stranger follow them around the racecourse. The racecourse had around thirty stands that had been set up for the race and the crowd was now massed around them. The stands were in various stages of disarray, it was difficult to see the runners and they were in different positions. We were soon calling out their names, one by one they would come running down the course. I was still in a crowd and only ran up the final few metres of the course before joining the marshalls. They had finished the course and all the runners were heading

0ral History The growing trend for historians to rely on oral evidence is not without its problems. It is naive to suppose that someone’s testimony represents a pure distillation of past experience for in an interview each party is affected by the other. At the very least, historians sometimes fail to listen to the witness and ignore the context for their own purposes. It is important for historians to ensure that the interviewee is not subject to undue influence, and that the interviewee is not biased by pre-existing ideas about the past. 
  
 As with all human endeavours, the process of conducting an interview will vary with the personality of the witness, the subject matter of the testimony and the researcher’s expectations. For example, a participant may reveal information or behaviour of no interest, or may have an interesting account but no useful information to add. The witness may say nothing of any use, provide useful but irrelevant information, or provide useful information but not of any immediate interest to the researcher. For this reason it is important for an interviewer to be tolerant, flexible and sensitive in conducting the interview. There is a particular case when the interviewee and the interviewer are at a crossroad, and it is important to respect that momentary pause and listen to the witness’s point of view. 
  
 There are different kinds of oral interviews, and interviews conducted for historical research may vary according to the purpose of the interview, the time and the medium in which it is conducted. 
  
 An interview conducted for historical research may be the best form of oral testimony as it allows for a frank exchange of information and allows the interviewer to identify relevant background information that could not be found in the original

'You don't take sugar do you? shouted his secretary not so much asking a question as stating a fact - as well she might because she had been making Lancelot cups of coffee for many months. Her excuse for forgetting such things was that he wasn’t normally supposed to be there. But you never knew when some of his friends or their families might want their tea in sugar.'Lancelot had been the chief surgeon at the Hospital of Saint Luke, near London, for many years. He had run it with his wife Susannah, a competent nurse. Now she retired and took up her position as governess at All Souls' school in a quiet rural village where she was popular with the children. Lancelot liked teaching the younger ones, as he was fond of telling Susannah; they would have a great future. It seemed to help their popularity with their schoolteacher, Mr. Smith, that one of the children had recently won a prize at another school, which Mr. Smith thought very well for the boy to have. He was often given the same prizes by All Saints. This was an opportunity that he had been eager to take, and he was especially proud when the school was asked to collect all the prizes for the next exhibition. It was always an enormous job to collect the prizes, in which all schools were interested. He took the opportunity to send Lancelot and Susannah away early on the morning of the event. He took the boys to a nearby country club, where he told them the news. Then he and Susannah went for a walk, to let the news take effect. The following day, they all met again in his office. There was much laughter over the prizes. And then the moment of truth came. He told them,

REMOVAL DAY With her children now grown widowed Susan faces leaving the family home. The van said Susan noticed ‘Removers of Distinction’ and indeed every distinguishing feature of the house was being removed. Everything which made it particular was being wrapped in newspaper and packed in boxes by Fred the removal man his enormous fingers like sausages tenderly handling all the breakables and his team of helpers not so gentle. Mrs Henschke, however, was not to be hurried. She read all the newspapers in the house carefully looking for the one which she could sell and for which she might buy a more comfortable home. Mrs Henschke found it, so at last the day of her departure was confirmed. She wrote a letter of resignation in the hand which had held hers all these years and packed away everything else she had left. She then threw the letter away. The removal men arrived about eleven. Susan had written the letter just as the men arrived. The day she had finally left she had written the letter in the hand with which she had held it all these years. To everyone present it had appeared as a real resignation. After she had written it the van had been loaded and the last of the family were driven away to start their new life. The removal vans drove in silence to the site of a new house being constructed on a larger land estate but it was near to the family home. Everyone was sad to see Susan go. The family were glad the move was finally over. They were still to leave but it was not too late. The next day the children, now adults, met on the small patch of grass near the old house for the last time. Everyone was sad to leave but it was only just after the farewell tea when they looked up and saw the house ahead of them with the white awning and red bricks on the ground. Mrs Henschke, in

Screen Learning A few days ago I noticed my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth while trying to look fierce. ‘I’m a little dinosaur’ he said. He was play-acting a scene from a recent TV programme so I quizzed him about what he remembered about dinosaurs. Then he revealed his favourite dinosaur was Triceratops. He’d seen a Triceratops statue in London and he asked me to get it for him. ‘I’ve been dreaming of it!’ he said. There are many children’s books with Triceratops in them. His dinosaur was in the front of the Little Tikes Big Dinosaur Adventure Play set (see review). Our first stop was an art gallery, and next up was a Chinese restaurant. There’s really no way that dinosaur could eat a meal of noodles! It’s not very tall, the dinosaur has two hooves and it has a beak in its mouth. It also lacks teeth, although the dinosaur has a funny-looking, wagging tail. I thought this dinosaur might be a little too real to eat real noodles, even though children are used to it. That’s okay though, this is a cartoon. I wanted the dinosaur to know it was just a cartoon, not real life. The last meal he has for a while. I showed him how to make eggnog and a little bit of chocolate. He helped to mix it all up and then he tried it himself. He didn’t really want to. Build it yourself at the UK’s first bamboo bike workshop A course at the Bamboo Bike Club run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan buys you a computer-designed custom frame plus a fun weekend of bike-building.
The Bamboo Bike Club is an engineering-led group with the mission of creating an ever-growing, inclusive, and fun community for builders, crafters, and cyclists.
Our courses have been running since 2014 at King's College in central London. A two-day workshop is designed for builders and bike-builders, as well as for cyclists, and has a lot to teach, including techniques for using the latest bamboo, carbon fibre, wood, and stainless steel materials.
Every workshop has four hours of workshop time, followed by a weekend for building. A “building day” is an important part of building any piece of kit, and is one of the best ways to create a lasting attachment to your new machine, to the people working on it, and to the community that surrounds it. Building day is a chance to get creative and spend quality time with friends and fellow enthusiasts, rather than to work and concentrate on a project alone for days on end.
Our building workshop has all you need - an all-inclusive frame, a quality toolskit, advice on choosing materials, and some bamboo bikes already on the frame! A two-day workshop costs £2,500. The building day costs £350.
Choose to spend £2500 on a 2-day course and building day, or choose to pay £2,000 and build a fully custom bike yourself. A one-day workshop costs £450. For more information or to register your interest,

Vervet monkeys Cheney and Seyfarth describe how one day the dominant male in the group of vervet monkeys they were studying noticed a strange male hanging around in a neighbouring grove of trees. The stranger’s intentions were quite obvious: he was sizing up the group in order to join it. The dominant monkey soon returned to his place. But when the stranger came around in the other direction, one of the vervets shot him a death-blow with his long, sharp teeth. The dominant monkey seemed indifferent. “We thought this was odd: a group of monkeys doing a little hunting and maybe taking something to eat. It wasn’t until we got closer that we realised the stranger was a human in disguise.” Once the monkeys had killed him, “we could see it was a man” who had come to the jungle looking for food. That was four years ago, in December 2014. The killer monkeys still won’t let him near the female monkeys. The Vervet Monkey Project wants us to help it understand the reasons for the death. Did this human go in search of food, or was there a conflict between humans and the vervet monkeys? Is there a new human living in the jungle where the monkeys have no contact? Or was the man lured to the place where he was killed? Did the vervet monkeys kill him with their own teeth? Are they looking for revenge? What was the man’s purpose in visiting the jungle? Why was he killed? Was it by a female? Was it by a rival group of monkeys, or could it be that a man was killed by the vervet monkeys? Are there still humans living in the jungle? I have no idea. The best I can think of is that maybe

AESTHETICS By one of the ironic perversities that often attend the course of affairs the existence of the works of art upon which formation of aesthetic theory depends has become an obstruction to theory about them. For one reason: these works are products that exist externally and physically. That is why when people in theory are writing about paintings or sculptures or drawings they refer to things that exist outside themselves. It is easier to write than to think of an image or a memory or a smell as an actual object or entity and then write in a way that allows one to apprehend that object or entity. I therefore try to find a middle ground between these two extremes. I have tried to combine the fact that the form of the object must be apprehended as an actual entity with the fact that the object must have some intrinsic meaning. It is necessary to understand the object of art and its objectivity. Then we must be able to see some form of meaning in the object itself. In order to do that we must be able to imagine the process and then in a way visualize it. That has been my aim. I hope to show that these works of art may be made to have a certain function which requires some imagination. Aesthetic studies, theoretical or practical, cannot be limited to images and ideas alone, they should include a certain process, an objectivity and a subjectivity, a relation between the human beings who think about the work of art and the objects of art and an interrelation between theory and practice. I believe that in order to see what I mean by that we have to study more of the objects themselves and not only look at what they look like. We have to be able to imagine what process might be used to make them into something we can actually understand and appreciate

Sand Much as I admire sands miraculous ability to be transformed into useful objects like glass and concrete I am not a great fan of it in its natural state. To me it is primarily a hostile barrier that stands between a seaside car park and the water itself. It blows in your face gets in your sandwiches and swallows vital objects like car keys and coins. One of the latest examples is this sculpture at the British Museum that I saw recently. It was titled "Sandstorm", it was made out of various natural materials including limestone and lime and it stood on top of the sand. It took about a year to create and cost about 20 million pounds. You could argue that it is quite beautiful, but I think it is rather useless as it stands. As we all know sand is not a great conductor of heat, and it seems the sand is just there for decoration rather than for insulation. This is particularly true if it is made of limestone which would be the case with sandstorm, it acts as a conductor. It is no surprise then that over the years people have come up with various solutions to this problem. In my view one of the most obvious ones has been the creation of insulating sand. This has to be the most obvious way of reducing the conductivity of sand. A simple idea to reduce the conductivity of sand is to turn the material into glass-like structures that can actually conduct electricity. This would essentially mean creating sand glass. It is rather an interesting idea that can be applied in a variety of ways, one of the more interesting ways being through sandcastles. However, one of the problems with these sandcastles is that they are made from limestone, which can be a very expensive material. If this is the most obvious solution then there must be other ideas out there. I guess we will never know, as it

Art on TV Why is it that television so consistently fails when it comes to programmes about the visual arts? Painting and sculpture should be natural subjects for the camera which has the ability to show a whole work of art then move in close to examine the details. It doesn't matter who the artist is, or what they are doing. They have got to be more interesting than a painting that covers the same ground over and over. Painting and sculpture are so much more exciting and engaging to watch than reality TV. 
  
 The answer lies in our culture of instant gratification. We want to see the finished product. With reality TV it is never just the finished product, it is always an ongoing process where each episode must always be an amazing revelation. We want to see the finished product. 
  
 Reality TV, like painting and sculpture, should be more interesting than a painting that covers the same ground over and over. 
  
 Let's be honest. The paintbrush isn't the most exciting tool in the world to watch. 
  
 If we could go back in time and had the chance to change the way the world works then maybe we wouldn't just paint the same old same old. We would actually paint some truly spectacular art. Let's make TV great again.

The Actor’s Craft Derision and contempt are sprayed at actors from time to time. Much of this disdain is fuelled by the actors themselves when they’re compelled by their film/theatre companies to talk about their craft (and themselves) in interviews. Many actors have done the “actors’ craft” derision on TV shows such as The Young Ones and The Archers, so it isn’t a surprise to find a similar tone here. However, the vitriol is particularly loud and bitter this time round, coming straight from the mouths of the members of the theatre company itself. The actor’s guilds are generally considered to be bastions of professional actors and I’m sure they’re usually as nice as you’ll ever get. Well, this is an exception to the rule.
From the opening scenes, there is no attempt by the cast to make us believe this is anything other than a straightforward parody. It’s a simple gag that has been recycled in every show for decades, a classic gag of which is “the theatre is run by lunatics”. In most cases it is the director’s idea to do this, not the actors. In other cases it’s a gag written and set by the actors and rehearsed by the cast. In the first case, the opening is set out by the director, in the second case the cast rehearses it together, and, in the last case, the actors improvise a bit. There are no clues as to which direction was chosen for any of the sketches except in the opening scenes.
So, here we have the players in the same roles but as the characters they are

Work Theodore Zeldin looks at how our working life could change. Are you as respected and appreciated as you deserve? Success in a career is no longer enough. Every profession is complaining that it is not properly valued or understood and even among individuals who have won eminence there is often bitterness behind the fame. One example is the American business writer and sociologist Zeldin. He thinks that in his profession of economic analyst one is not sufficiently valued and recognised. In the first place, it is hard to get a job as a researcher. And as the specialist he must also take on additional work as economist, economist and sociologist. “It’s a lot like teaching” says Zeldin. “Only I have to give up my teaching post and concentrate on all my work as sociologist.” When I ask him about his work he is extremely proud. He has written several books, which are popular worldwide. “Our society has become highly complex and more and more people are very interested in economic problems. These subjects have not been written about properly before.” In the United States there are many books written by Zeldin on such subjects as the value of work, salaries, working conditions and pensions. He is also interested in the working life of people from different backgrounds and countries. He has travelled all over the world and he is always interested in the cultures and ideas of other cultures. “Many interesting things happen in our society and many of them I write about in my books.” He thinks that one day our society will have to know how much it is valued and appreciate this. I have asked him if he ever regrets not having had a traditional job. “What is the good of a traditional job? Why should I work only

Language You and I belong to a species with a remarkable ability we can shape events in each others brains with exquisite precision. Language is so tightly woven into human experience that it is scarcely possible to imagine life without it. Chances are that if you find two or more people together anywhere on earth they will soon be exchanging words.  If people had no language we could certainly not understand each other, yet there is a great deal of variation among human languages. It is believed that about 80-90% of languages are not fully understood by their speakers. There are so many different language speakers, the total number of known languages is believed to be as much as 500,000. This is remarkable, because there are only 10,000 known languages in the world! And each language can represent completely a different culture and its values. When I look into the eyes of someone who speaks an unknown language I find a great deal of magic. I have heard stories about two men who lived in a remote village in the Canadian Arctic. These men did not communicate much with each other. They lived separately and had little contact with other people. However they knew one another by name, and one day when the other men were not in the village they found the man with whom they shared their special name. As they made their way home the man with the special name was accompanied by a hunter who had been tracking the animal they were looking for.  As they passed a group of Eskimos the hunter recognized the man's name and was able to tell the two men where to go. They made it safely to the village, and one by one the two men spoke to the other men and they were able to understand one another. They discussed the recent events that had taken place. Kinetic Art Rejoice — the well-nigh impossible has happened: London’s austere Hayward Gallery has been transformed into a place full of wonder. And not thankfully by some huge-budget mega-hyped multi-media extravaganza but by a charmingly idiosyncratic investigation into an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years. A new exhibition traces the history of kinetic art — that is art which is concerned with movement — in the twentieth century. As part of an ongoing project, it presents a single object from each of the five decades, for each of those decades. It then presents a sequence of images illustrating its content, accompanied by a brief narrative. A few years ago, I was surprised to find a single image from the fiftieth year – the first such exhibition in over three hundred years. It had been lost for centuries, but was finally rediscovered last year. Now it appears in this year’s show.
This time, the gallery is transformed into a kind of museum, where visitors are free to browse the objects. Many are surprisingly contemporary. A photograph taken in 1949 – which I cannot find now – shows a woman with her back to the camera but looking directly at the viewer, with a rather charmingly casual grin. And a photograph by Kaws in 1971 is set in a futuristic cityscape, with futuristic buildings looking back at us, their balconies set on either side of a wide central space. A few seconds later an image from 1950 shows a man pushing a baby stroller into a futuristic building, all of which are silhouetted against the sky. A few seconds after that, a child on a scooter pushes a shopping cart down the street, and a later image depicts a man in a wheelchair pushing another. The sequence of images finishes with a short sequence illustrating some of the text. I should have taken some notes, but I forgot. There is also a short film illustrating the work,

Paul Simon Rock and roll in the 1950s was primarily a youth cult but its lasting importance lay in the seismic impact it had on the middle class and the middle-aged. It also paved the way for the next generation of rock idols who listened to it awestruck and aware that this strange unsettling sound would somehow irrevocably be linked with their destinies. As the music changed so did Rock and Roll and this evolution still continues. 
  
 For the next generation of bands like Journey, the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and U2, playing rock and roll became less about experimentation and more about commerce. Rock and Roll was their vehicle to the big time. 
  
 But that was only the beginning of Rock’s influence on popular music. His music was later turned into movies, TV shows and pop art. When Simon and Garfunkel sang We Wish You A Merry Christmas in 1967, they were turning their music into art. 
  
 The impact of the songs in movies has been huge as was evident with A Star Is Born, the remake of the classic movie, with Bradley Cooper and Lady Gaga. 
  
 In the film, the two have an incredible duet and when Cooper sings a line about a girl who will never be his, Gaga sings her back. They are one of the most iconic duets in music history. 
  
 But for me, what is most amazing about this music from the 50s is that the Beatles songs were not the only ones made famous. Other famous Beatles songs were covered and made famous by others. POETRY RECITALS At any given time in history the literary scene will seem confused to those who are living through it and it is the selectivity of posterity that makes the pattern and orders of eminence appear clearly defined to the retrospective view. Poetry is written in times of crisis and often written in a state of distress; the poetry of despair and disillusionment was a consequence of our war. One of the tragedies of the great poem is that when a poet is alive we are not able to see his poetry with that keen perception of art that we would have had in the absence of war. We are forced to form our judgements from the limited and imprecise materials which, at best, the public press provides for our amusement. There has been some slight improvement in the condition of this public press since the outbreak of war. Poetry, to a greater or lesser extent, was published and heard on the radio last year. There are some good poems which appeared in the paper and there have been a few very good ones, but there remains a certain degree of superficiality on the part of all writers, a slowness of development, and an inability to take the reader to the depths of their emotions and experiences. There is little or no poetry of a serious nature in most of the papers. Our poets are often too busy and too proud and too self-righteous to write poems of beauty. We have become a nation of poets, yes, poets with no real talent. But there are those who are so gifted, so subtle, so lyrical and elusive, that their words can only be heard by those with the right ear, the ear of true poets. And their words may never be printed in the papers. Po

CRYING Charles Darwin thought that the human tendency to cry had no obvious evolving purpose. He was almost certainly wrong. More recently scientists have pointed to its social significance with psychiatrist John Bowlby highlighting the role of crying in developing the attachment between mother and child. Many believe that tears at least during childhood are mainly an expression of helplessness. In humans crying is usually not linked to pain. Rather, it is more likely to result from emotional exhaustion. Although crying may result from the emotion of joy, sadness, or fear, it is less likely to be spontaneous than is laughter. One could argue that our natural human tendency to cry arises from our desire to show other people our feelings. Indeed, children will often cry inconsolably when another child is in trouble or when the parent feels that their child is being treated unfairly. In other words, we cannot be too careful about protecting our children from emotional turmoil as they grow into adults. If they are unhappy, our own feelings will undoubtedly be upset too. The need to protect them from pain and rejection often explains why they cry. Because of this, parents are taught early on to cry with a child when they become upset. When children learn to cry, it reinforces an association between being sad and being sad. So they will continue to cry in future. However, our human tendency to cry might explain why we humans appear so unable to remain happy. A recent study has demonstrated that our behaviour is more likely to remain positive for longer if we are crying. Crying also triggers a feeling of guilt and depression, and this has been linked to increased feelings of happiness and low levels of sadness. This is one reason why we humans often seem more cheerful when we are happy, and our feelings of regret, anger and sadness. The reason behind this may be that we often think of ourselves as more

Blogging: Confessing to the world Some time ago a website highlighted the risks of public check-ins – online announcements of your where-abouts. The site’s point was blunt: you may think you are just telling the world ‘Hey I’m at this place’ – but you are also advertising your out-and-about-ness to all kinds of people everywhere – not all of them people you might like to bump into. This risk is heightened for those of us who are bloggers – as the site’s title suggests, this is a way to confess to the world (and your readers) where your whereabouts are. However, as it’s a confession, I’m thinking I should perhaps confess all – not just to the world but also to those readers. So here I am, in the blogosphere, admitting I’m at the house of a friend and his wife. That’s what I had for dinner, I think. The title I chose because you are unlikely to ever see anything like it. If I hadn’t been blogging, the title would have been a giveaway. And, even if I had chosen not to blog, ‘My Friend and His Wife’ (as my blog’s title is all-too-often used) would still have been an odd choice of words. For a start, I’m single. For another, my friend is married and his wife is, I think, not a very nice woman. Oh, and I’ve got a blog. If this is true, I think I prefer to be called ‘My Friend and His Wife, and Theirs Is Not a Nice House’. Anyway, back to confession. So, why am I revealing my whereabouts online? Food There is something very elemental and satisfying about our relationship with food. I know I may be preaching to the converted because presumably people keen on cooking buy cookery books like this one but so often we imagine that unless it is some special occasion or an especially elaborate dish it is hardly worth attempting. Cooking can be a very rewarding experience for the person who does it and a challenge, both of which I am certain can be gained with the right ingredients. This book gives a comprehensive selection of the latest ingredients and methods for cooking, and is both a good guide to learning how to cook some of these new ideas, and a book that will be appreciated by people who are keen to cook. It is well worth considering.
The book is designed as a guide to many of the latest technologies available for cooking - from electric stoves to food dehydrators to wine coolers - but it also includes many techniques such as baking and roasting. It is also quite clear and detailed in describing the various products available and where to find them. In short, it is an excellent guidebook for anyone wanting to become a good cook. I am not a great cook, but I do like to cook, and this book is definitely on the way to my library.

The Lure of the Kitchen When I was at university I decided I wanted to be a chef. Among my contemporaries this was an unusual choice. Cooking was not one of the plum jobs that most of us wanted. It is on the face of it an unattractive profession. Chefs lead notoriously harsh lives: the work is long pressured menial - and badly paid. The hours are long and the meals are uninspiring. 
  
 Many of my mates opted for careers in other fields. Others opted to start their own business. But I decided to become a chef. It was a simple decision that I was convinced of. But as the years passed I began to realise that this could be a very hard life, even if the meals were tasty. 
  
 When I became a chef, my life was very different. My house in London was filled with chefs. I knew all of them. I knew their jobs, their families, their friends. It took a lot of time and a great deal of effort to form a real friendship with anyone. The most I could do was to pass around a plate of food. 
  
 The thing that always worried me most about the profession was the amount of stress that chefs endure. The demands of the job can take an enormous toll on your physical and mental health. 
  
 After I decided that I would love the job, my life took on an entirely new direction. It wasn't long before my wife and I made the move to London. I began to cook meals in restaurants on a regular basis. But I never dreamed of cooking my own meals. At my favourite restaurants, I would sit around a table and share my thoughts and ideas with others. It was my way of being in the kitchen all the time, sharing my knowledge.

TIM RICE I was ushered into the young man’s drawing room an oasis of cultured sanity surrounded by what appeared to be a quite shambolic cluster of rooms in which the less enterprising members of the family operated. Moving from the kitchen to his parlour was an upgrade from economy to business class. This wasn’t the way to the kitchen, it was the way to the dining room. “Welcome to my home.” His mother was a tall woman in a red dressing gown. She sat across from him in one of his armchairs. “I know you’re probably tired from all the traveling but if you could be patient with me for a while I have something I need to tell you in private.” “Not at all. You’ve earned my trust by staying away from the business so long. I’m the man who’s going to make a killing on these old family farms. And I’ve done it for the right reasons.” Who is the murderer?“What a tangled web we weave, when first we practise to deceive.”

- Hamlet (3:5)
