Advertising on trial If you work for an advertising agency the early years of the 1990s may well have been the toughest of your professional life. The recession in business was bad enough. It was longer deeper and more severe than anticipated by even the most pessimistic hitting industrialised nations as hard as anything else for thirty years. So if you worked in an advertising agency in the 1990s and found yourself in a situation where the clients were looking for advertising agencies to help them make advertising decisions they were often looking for someone to sell to. They could not afford it, and they would only consider it if they had the money available to buy it. If they were also looking for advertising agencies to make them sell their company’s advertising, they also couldn’t afford it. This was the situation most agencies faced.
They had few clients, and with fewer clients came few opportunities. And of those few, very few were willing to pay for good work. So the agency was very slow in paying commission to its employees. But there were some small agencies where a quick turnaround from start to finish, with good quality work, was very profitable. These were the ones that were doing good work quickly. In these agencies the clients were usually willing to pay a reasonable wage and do good work in return. The problem with this way of working was that it was more difficult to build and maintain a strong client base of reliable advertisers, and these were difficult to build.
When the recession hit, the agencies also had to keep their staff costs down as much as possible, although it could be very difficult to do.

How to Write Poetry Telling people how to write poetry is a bit like frolicking through a minefield: spontaneity is the order of the day but one false step and a dozen certainties will blow up in your face. This page gives pointers to make sure your poetry is of a high standard and to avoid becoming one of those annoying poets who keeps on posting his or her work over and over.

One important point of style for a poet is keeping a consistent cadence. The idea that you should repeat a rhyme or phrase over and over is a bit archaic for the new generation of writers. The best poetry does it in such a way that you would never guess at how it is being said. One of the best ways to do this is to just recite the poem word-for-word after reading it.
Poetry can sometimes be used to make a point. You can often tell something about the speaker from his or her poetry. If the speaker is trying to make a point about something, he or she would say something like: “… and I’ll just leave you with this…” (If you really can’t remember what a poem is about, read some books on poetry.) If the poem is used to show what the speaker is thinking, he or she would use a short phrase like: “You know, it’s funny how…” (“You know, it’s funny how…” is used to show how you would think it is funny if the speaker said the same thing without any punctuation.) This is one of the most important parts of the style that is commonly used in poetry. The poet�

Online Literary Criticism For All Do-it-yourself literary criticism: more than just harmless fun? From the outset the idea of open access to the Internet was one of its guiding principles. In theory anyone could publish a manifesto or broadcast a music channel on the Internet. In practice however a certain amount of technical know-how was required at least in the early years. Then the concept of the internet as an open library was born in the late 1990s. It became possible to put books online which previously would not have been available to the general public. However, if a user is willing to take some initial measures, he can have access to the literature of the past many centuries without the need of special equipment. In this context the first online literary criticism sites appeared in 2001: http://academia.stackexchange.com in January. Since then several millions of people have already used the online literary criticism on the Internet. It is also no longer necessary to have specialized knowledge to be able to participate in a discussion. This new online literary criticism system is known as “literary criticism for all”. Even if it involves a bit of technical know-how, it does not take up a lot of time. In fact most literary critics nowadays would not hesitate to accept requests to write reviews on a book they are studying at university. This online literary criticism system has a number of advantages. On the one hand, it encourages literary criticism more widely and at lower cost. On the other hand, the Internet gives people all over the world access to the literature of the past. The Internet also acts as a platform on which to share knowledge and ideas in the general literature. These two advantages are especially important in the post-modern world. The online literary criticism has made it possible for people to find a way to express themselves in a language they

Love them fear them worship them human culture has always had a lot to say about birds. But what does that say about us? Paul Evans reports There's a bump bump bump coming from the greenhouse as a little brown shuttlecock bounces against the glass. It turns out to be a wren: an ominous bird a bird of portent augury and divination. This is a bird of the south, a native of Britain and north Africa, an ancient and legendary bird. And if it says "I feel something coming" then I think we all feel something coming, a global, historic crisis of enormous proportions. Not just in the Middle East, where we are seeing a succession of genocides and wars. Not just in North America where thousands of Indians and others are marching in the streets in anger. It is happening all over the planet. "This is the most violent and dangerous period in the history of our species," says one of our leading scientists. It is also a time of intense cultural, artistic and spiritual awakening. The word has just entered the vocabulary of humanity. It has entered our culture. It is not a coincidence. It is an expression of what's been going on for the last 200,000 years. The word is an invitation. How will you answer? Who knows? It may be nothing. Or it may be everything. For the past 2,000 years, as I have studied the origins of man, I've looked for the root cause of so many of our problems: our fear, our greed, our desire for more, even our hatred, our anger, our violence and our hatred of ourselves. Joanna’s Lessons Joanna MacGregor has a hectic schedule as a concert pianist. So why has she added the task of writing books for young children learning the piano? Even a member of that mythical species the completely tone deaf could not fail to be stirred by a Joanna MacGregor performance. But, what is so magical about these books? They are not books about music. The main character of Joanna's Lessons is a baby learning how to sit, walk and talk. The author makes sure that each movement has a sound, a movement that is accompanied by the sound of a particular bell. These books help you teach your baby a little bit about the world around them, while also encouraging the child to learn to play the piano. Joanna's lessons is based on this simple concept and could be seen as a kind of 'learn to walk' baby book for music lovers. The lessons are given to the baby in intervals. These intervals are the time between the bell sounds that remind us that music, as we know it, is always played. 
  
 The book is also a great companion for parents, teaching them to appreciate music when they were themselves unaware of it, while also encouraging them to get in the habit of learning from a young age. 
  
 The book is perfect for those parents who want to introduce a child to classical music but do not want to give the child classical lessons. While at the same time they still want the child to learn to sit and play the piano. 
  
 It also has a great educational value as it teaches young children to recognise different sounds. There are some children who may struggle to recognise some of the sounds in the book but the way the book is designed, they will come to understand these sounds

Every Picture Tells a Story Adapting novels for film almost always involves a process of reduction condensation and deletion. This can be very frustrating for the writer but also illuminating. Working on a script I was struck by how much of the dialogue and narrative description in a given scene in the novel I could dispense with while still getting across the same point.

For the story we wanted to tell, it didn't matter that much whether the words "craning its head" or "giggling" appeared in a scene, so long as the reader understood what the characters were doing.
For the dialogue, the character is telling a story and so the words tell a story in the form of a sentence. Words become sentences when read aloud, and this is where I feel I'm most comfortable. I wrote a screenplay of my novel and it works best when read aloud. If I'm reading the screenplay and a scene or line isn't clear, I can rephrase the dialogue to make it explicit. Sometimes the same is true of the writing itself, too. The prose is the essence of a novel, and so I'm naturally most comfortable with that form.
One of the things I liked about writing the screenplay was trying to be the director. With the novel, I would have found that hard to do, since I'm not a natural director. The screenplay I wrote was an attempt to see if that could be done.

The Heat is On We’ve all heard of global warming but just how much warmer will the earth get and how will it affect our lives? Almost everyone has some idea of what global warming is all about but no one is quite sure about its consequences. A warmer climate is likely to mean changes to the weather in all parts of the world. It is likely that the number of heat-related deaths will increase. In a warmer world, water resources will be more easily evaporated, causing flooding and drought. The availability of fresh drinking water is likely to be significantly affected. The number of heat-related illnesses and deaths is likely to increase. In a warmer world, the risk of desertification is likely to increase significantly and the frequency and severity of droughts is likely to increase. Desertification is the loss of vegetation and soil that can provide for the growing of crops. It is the loss of fertile land and is a major factor in migration, social instability, food and water crisis and wars. A warmer world will also mean more rainfall than the present world. There is a high likelihood that extreme rainfall events will occur more frequently. This will lead to floods, water wars and food crises. It will also lead to soil erosion and degradation. Global warming is set to have a serious negative impact on agricultural production in the future. There is high likelihood that the number of people who depend on agriculture will increase significantly. There are likely to be food riots in the world, as a result of increased food prices. There is high likelihood that the number of people in poverty, particularly in countries such as Africa, is likely to increase significantly. Maps The purpose of a map is to express graphically the relations of points and features on the earth’s surface to each other. These are determined by distance and direction. In a general sense, they serve as a set of graphical coordinates by which an observer can locate the position of another object on a coordinate system. In this article, we consider two kinds of maps — surface maps and contour maps. In surface maps, the features appear on the map as lines on the surface of the Earth, and the lines represent the positions of the points on the map. The contour maps appear on the map with a contour which traces the contours of points and features on the surface of the Earth. The contour map expresses an observer’s position on the surface in coordinates which are different from coordinates in the surface of the Earth. This kind of map is used by astronauts to locate objects on the surface and find their positions. The surface maps in space are created by printing a special material, called “polychromatic ink,” on paper in a shape which will reflect light as a sphere will. The polychromatic ink reflects light from specific angles, and is thus a surface map. The surface of Earth is a sphere, so the surface map reflects light from all angles, which reflects the positions of all points on the Earth at different angles. The surface of the Earth reflects the light from the surface map to the center of the sphere, so the position of the surface map on the sphere is the same as the positions of the points on the Earth at all other angles. The position of the surface map at any angle above the central axis

Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a rough idea of what he did. He was the leader of the 1911 Antarctic expedition. He used the skills and experience he had to reach the Antarctic, where they went to find a way to avoid becoming trapped in ice for three years. That’s a huge distance and it takes a lot of skill, but his ship, Endurance, was a formidable vessel. His leadership helped his team reach safety. It was a big, mighty ship made of iron. He was famous afterwards and everyone was interested to know what he did next. He went back to Europe to work for the Royal Navy. In 1912 he became the director of South Georgia and was responsible for keeping the Falklands safe and welcoming ships and people back to South Georgia. In the latter part of the 20th century we saw a rapid increase in the opportunities available for listening to music through radio TV records tapes CDs videos and a rapidly developing range of multi-media techniques. This paper offers an assessment of the technology developed and the impact it has had on our music production output in Britain. A key finding is that the pace of technology is increasing. As a result music produced in Britain has not kept pace. It is noted that the majority of recorded music in the UK was produced in the 1950s but by the mid-1970s this was not the case. There is an urgent need to address this problem. The impact of technology on our music has also had an effect on public culture. Radio has become a primary way of listening to music with over 98% of British people listening to the radio in the home, a figure that has grown steadily over recent years. The impact of technology on music production and on our public culture is discussed with examples drawn from the music industry, the BBC, the music media and the culture industry in the context of the last 20 years. As well as assessing the impact it has had on our public culture, the paper considers the development of technological solutions for addressing the problem. It concludes that it is imperative that new technologies be developed to help overcome this technological challenge. Holiday reading Summer promises us two of life’s great joys: escaping home and reading books - joys that are of course intimately connected. Books may help us to feel more at home in the world at large. We can relate our experiences to those described in great books written long ago or in distant lands because there are fewer human types than there are people. That may explain why we relate so strongly to The Lord of the Rings. Reading is like travel: we are transported to a place where we belong, and this is one of the great pleasures of reading. But more importantly, reading can provide us with a new understanding of life’s difficulties and triumphs, helping us to see the world through a different point of view. Our ability to grasp these two pleasures - pleasure and understanding - depends to some extent on our ability to read. And as children and teenagers, we may be in the best position to help ourselves improve our ability to read. As with anything else in life, to improve our ability to read is also a way of learning more about yourself. That can help us to understand ourselves as individuals and as a society. In the next article, we will explore this idea. We will look at the importance of reading to children and teenagers, with a particular focus on teenagers. Our ideas about reading are constantly changing. We need to keep pace with the latest developments in this field. The article will look at current developments in this field, including some of the latest advances in pedagogy, methods and the impact of technology on this area of learning. Photography When a photographer takes a photograph he or she makes a selection of visual information that is determined by his or her technical and aesthetic skills personal views and experience together with a set of social and cultural norms. A picture has three basic components that combine to form an image in the mind’s eye.

The photographer has a vision, which is the basic idea of what he or she intends to present to the world. Vision can be expressed through ideas and imagery, or a visual representation of those ideas.

The photographer has the opportunity to realize that vision and to share it with others.

Photography can have positive or negative impact on society. However, it can also serve as a force for social change. The more people see, the more they can learn about themselves, their world, and how to live. How to choose between a good photograph and an embarrassing photograph?

Photography has a huge potential to help people in their everyday lives. One example of a positive impact would be improving understanding and appreciation of nature. On the other hand, photographers are faced with a large range of problems and situations, which can be very distressing and disturbing for them and can lead to a lot of difficulties in terms of the composition and overall artistic quality of their photographs. It is difficult for a professional photographer to find a good balance between the demands on their time and their psychological state. In addition, the pressures are constantly increasing because of the demands made on photographers by a demanding business environment and a consumer base increasingly demanding the best. On the other hand, photographers’ business models rely heavily on the volume of work they receive, and their livelihood is linked to that of their clients

Vancouver In the last ten years or so hundreds of thousands of people from all over the world have taken up residence in Vancouver in western Canada. To relax in the evening residents stroll down the city streets and if you join them you are likely to overhear a different language at almost every other step. This is because Vancouver is the English speaking Capital of Canada. There is a vibrant city life for the residents of Vancouver, however it is not without its problems. With a population over one million people, Vancouver's transport system is the largest in Canada and therefore it is difficult to find parking places for vehicles in Vancouver. This is one of the reasons why, when you want to get around in Vancouver, you are most likely to use a car instead of public transport. Vancouver is an exciting city but it can also be a crowded one. It is therefore important to know the different options you have when planning your visit to Vancouver. It's also important to know how to use these different options in a safe and clean way so you do not get yourself into trouble. This article will help you make the most of the city you are visiting, even when you have limited time to do it! Vancouver is a city in British Columbia, Canada and the capital of the province of British Columbia. It is located on the Strait of Georgia, approximately 100 km (62 mi) north of the Strait of Georgia (also known as the South Sound), between Vancouver Island and southern Fraser Valley of British Columbia. The city includes the Vancouver International Airport and is home to Canada's second-largest city and fifth largest metropolitan area. The city is governed by a municipal government, which is composed of the City Council and the Board of Trade. The mayor of the city is named Peter Port. Vancouver has a population of approximately 650,

MUSIC AND THEATRE Up until quite recently I would have said that opera is first and foremost theatre. Not any more. After a brief spell working at u national opera house I learned that opera is in fact only secondly theatre. The music comes first. That’s as it should be of course. But the opera house has no place in a good theatre, a great theatre is one which nurtures the arts and the art form. A theatre with an opera house is one which is far from being great. The more I see of the contemporary art world the more I am aware of the fact that opera is, by far, the most important artistic form of the twenty-first century. It is still, for me, as important as painting and architecture. And as I look for new ways to get people excited about opera I am increasingly coming to believe that the best way is to give them a compelling and engaging theatre to do so. That is the problem I have with theatre critics that write about theatre. It is not that their assessments are wrong. On the contrary, there is a vast amount of great work by a whole generation of contemporary playwrights that is still awaiting a place at a top theatre like the Royal Shakespeare Company. Rather their evaluations are not objective, but based on the perception of their readership. Or rather, they are not objective at all. Many are simply opinion based, as is the case with theatre critics as a whole. Their job is largely to write for those on the inside of theatre and to report what they think. That job requires them to be objective of a sort. Otherwise they wouldn’t be journalists. But that objective nature is not really relevant. They write based on perceptions, and perceptions are the subject of the very review which they write.

BROADCASTING: The Social Shaping of a Technology 'Broadcasting' originally meant sowing seeds broadly by hand. It is in other words not only an agricultural metaphor it is also one of optimistic modernism. It is about planned growth in the widest possible circles the production if the conditions are right of a rich harvest. Broadcast, a radio transmission medium was made possible by the telegraph which connected two farms in order to send messages between them by land and by water. At the same time the telegraph became public property. As soon as a telegraph was erected in a city the whole countryside was covered by it in a matter of minutes. As soon as the telegraph was invented, a network of wires stretched across every town, village and hilltop. A line was established from the station in the city to the station at the foot of the hill, and a line from the station at the foot of the hill to the station at the top of the hill, thus all of a sudden all the people in the villages and the towns had access to telegraph. With the invention of the telegraph it did not take long for the telegraph to spread like a contagious disease from house to house, to take over the whole community. People were not surprised by this. The very idea of this spreading of a technology was considered in this context by the early modern thinkers. This was how the word broadcast came into the English language from Dutch broadcasting. BROADCASTING and it also means spreading seeds widely in all directions, including in the smallest of things. If only the telegraph had not spread so quickly and so wide. The expression broadcast comes from a French expression which means sowing in the widest of circles, and which also occurs from Dutch broadcasting. Broadcast in this context means spreading seeds broadly in all directions

Writing Reviews Frank Kermode examines the craft of review-writing from a practitioner’s point of view. Most reviews are written and circulated under conditions which ensure that they have a very short active life. This book attempts to show how this problem can be improved. There are seven chapters, two of which are very short. It is recommended reading for any writer who has been contemplating writing reviews. The review is a work of art. The book is available from the author.
The Review Writing Guide James M. Baruch reviews the principles and practice of writing review articles in the context of academic journals. It contains general principles and guidelines as well as specific tips for writers. The book is available from the publisher.
Review Writing as Art William Gibson discusses the subject of review writing in an informal manner. It covers both the theoretical and the practical aspects of writing reviews and suggests how this can be improved. This book is a useful guide to review writing as it is practiced by different groups of people. It is available from the publisher.
Review Writing for Journalists and Writers Paul A. Mays provides guidelines for writers to follow when attempting to produce good reviews. This book offers advice for both the journalist and the writer. The book is available from the publisher.
Review Writing: How to Do it Better Stephen Krashen writes on the topic of review writing in a self-help style. It looks at the different aspects of review writing and provides advice for the reader to improve his writing.
Review Writing: A Guide for the Writer David K. Wessin discusses in an informal and accessible style how to improve the quality of reviews. This book is intended for writers and journalists. It provides suggestions

Citizen Kane When the film Citizen Kane finally appeared in 1941 despite the brouhaha that attended its release - delayed because of distributor’s fears of the harm William Randolph Hearst its alleged subject might do to them - and largely ecstatic reviews it was not a commercial success. It was television that brought it back to the public consciousness. Now, at the behest of Charles Foster Kane, the playwright he loved (his mother is a major player in the play and will make her on-screen appearance shortly) the silent movie of the same name will be made into a dramatic film. But, instead of being presented by the Academy or Hollywood or both, the film will be presented, not by the Academy or Hollywood, but by a private screening club in New York City. Because of this, the play, which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1927, is being set to be produced as a film by a company called IFC, Inc. The company was named for what seems to be the name of a New York street corner. What’s IFC stand for? In order to find out, IFC has enlisted the help of a number of the industry’s most celebrated experts in the art of TV, which, as it turns out, is a big field. IFC, Inc. and their clients have gathered at Columbia University in New York City to talk about the project. This is what they’ve come for. There is a question of financing for the movie, which would cost far more than a typical silent movie, but IFC has the backing of the John F. Kennedy Foundation. England’s breakfast revolution The importance of a good breakfast is beyond dispute according to health experts but in historical terms breakfast is a relatively new arrival in England with descriptions of breakfast seldom featuring in medieval literature. The arrival of breakfast in England was partly a response to the need to improve the quality of the diet of farmers. As a result, some historians believe that the first mention of the word breakfast is to be found in medieval literature as early as 1399. In the 12th century, the English began to treat the morning meal as an important part of their daily diet with many English men writing books about how to cook a healthy breakfast. The success of the English Breakfast in England in the 12th century made it one of the most popular dishes of the period and a staple for English breakfast table for centuries. However, although the food was a massive success it did not go down well with the other residents of the country and it was made illegal in some areas. The first known recorded mention of breakfast in English literature is in 1399 when William de Beaumont of Ely recorded a letter from a man named Peter and his wife Elizabeth in which Peter wrote about the delicious breakfast that he had had that morning. Thereafter, many more examples of the breakfast meal were recorded, including the ones penned by Sir Edward Coke and other English writers, although in modern terms breakfast has become so widely understood that in many places the word breakfast has replaced the name of the meal. Today, the word breakfast has become a generic term for any meal that takes place at least half an hour before the start of the day meal.
